Unless you go there early in the morning, you will be sharing the Cenotes with numerous other people.  I personally prefer “off the beaten path” Cenotes, therefore the rating on these Cenotes reflect my personal preference.

Cenote Xkeken (aka Xquequen) is a “Cave Cenote”, while its neighbouring Cenote “Samula” (directly across the road) is a “Cavern Cenote”.  These Cenotes are completely separate from each other, each having separate entrance fees (of approx. 57 MX Pesos).  These Cenotes have been developed and are quite commercialized. There is a large parking lot for cars and tour buses, vendors, shops, washroom facilities, and optional life jacket rentals.  .

Cenote Xkeken, Cave Cenote, is lit up with artificial lighting, providing light to an impressive display of stalactites and what I assume are colourful mineral deposits in the rocks.  Lighting in this Cenote is necessary, as it would be pitch black if there were no artificial lighting, however the choice of having “changing coloured lights” was a bad idea. Dim white lights would be much better in preserving the natural integrity and beauty of the cave.  There is a walk-way around 1/3 of the Cenote providing various spots for families and swim gear. The stairs into the Cenote are very sturdy and user-friendly.

Cenote Samula is directly across the road from Xkeken. Samula is a Cavern Cenote which is lit by a natural hole in its ceiling where spectacular beams of sunlight penetrate the surface of the water  - - a natural skylight!  There are impressive stalactites and tree roots descending from the Cenote’s ceiling. There are sturdy stairs into the Cenote, however they are steeper than the neighbouring Cenote, and they can get a bit slippery, so caution is suggested. From the two Cenotes, Samula is by far my favourite Cenote.   

GPS Co-ordinates for Parking  = N 20 39.738, W 88 14.623

251858152.name: Disappointed
251858152.author: a TripAdvisor user
251858152.reviewBody: We took a shared minibus at Calle 41 and 44, and paid 20 pesos per person.  It took about 10 minutes.  There are two cenotes side by side. It took about two minutes walking down. It was a safe walk. It was a basically underground pool.  Nothing more and nothing less.  Some people were swimming.  We were not sure how clean the water was. We saw many bats droppings on rocks.  We took a few pictures and left. We spent about 10 minutes.  There  were two or three taxes waiting for customers from  cenotes. We paid 60 pesos for returning back to Valladolid.

250574653.name: Beautiful and peaceful
250574653.author: a TripAdvisor user
250574653.reviewBody: Water was beautiful and the area was very peaceful.\nWw were able to swim without a guide which was lovely.\n

249889520.name: Average
249889520.author: a TripAdvisor user
249889520.reviewBody: Dark, dank, damp. Very little natural light. A lot of artificial light. Electrical wires running everywhere. A lot of people.  The smell wasn\'t very nice.\n\nI\'ve been to a lot of cenotes, this was probably a least favorite.  It\'s worth seeing because the tiny hole at the top and the cavern structure, with the bats flying about, gives it a much different experience than other cenotes. However, as so far as enjoyment factor, I\'d say other cenotes have been more charming and enjoyable.

249222518.name: Refreshing dip
249222518.author: a TripAdvisor user
249222518.reviewBody: Nice place to take a dip- water is not as cold as some other cenotes. A little bit commercial in that there is a hallway of vendors you pass but not a big hassle. You can rent a mask and snorkle and life preserver. Bring your own towel. Plenty of room to change.

247376044.name: Swimming in a cave
247376044.author: a TripAdvisor user
247376044.reviewBody: Our first cenote; fun to walk down into cave.  Lit by small hole in roof, roots dangle above water. No need for life jackets or snorkel gear.  Had a yummy quick snack at the entrance.

246965829.name: Go to Setumal
246965829.author: a TripAdvisor user
246965829.reviewBody: Setulam cenote is really beautiful -- probably not the best for older travelers (long, steep staircase). Don\'t bother with Xkeken, crowded, bats, catfish, kind of gross.

246615507.name: Great local cenote
246615507.author: a TripAdvisor user
246615507.reviewBody: This a cenote very well known by locals and getting more tourist daily. It costs 59 pesos and it is in a cave. It is better to visit it around midday till 2pm to see the ray of light that comes through the hole in the ceiling. Beautiful. Also, in front of it there is another cenote called Setumal, it is less impressive but it is also in a cave. 59 pesos as well. You can swin in both of them, but it is nicer xkeken. You can get to both of them from Valladolid getting a colectivo (they are located in the corner of 44 and 41). If colectivos are full they will charge you no more than 20 or 25 pesos. If they are empty they might charge you the same as taxis (70 pesos per 2 ppl). You can also rent a bike in one of the hostels (hostel cinco calles or hostel el fraile) for 15 pesos/hour or 70/day and ride yourself 6km through a unpaved bike path. Another good option being in Valladolid is Cenote Oxman, 4 km away with the bike, just take Calzada de los Frailes till the church, turn right on 49 and left on 54 and is all straight. It costs 30 pesos and it is really nice (not known by tourists). Of course, cenote Zaci, downtown is really awesome, 25 pesos. Suggestion: if you want to visit everything in one day, take a colectivo to Xkeken and Setumal and then back and rent a bike to go to Oxman once you are back. We did Ek Balam in the morning, cenotes after than and finally Oxman with the bike. Cenotes close at 5.30pm

244707633.name: Dreamlike location
244707633.author: a TripAdvisor user
244707633.reviewBody:
We came early & had this to ourselves. Really amazing. Bats are chattering overhead and they fly around occasionally.
The water is very clear and lots of catfish swim around. Sunlight streams through a big hole in the roof. Tree roots make for a wonderful effect.
The water is really clear and not cold. Really magical effect.
Cost of 59 pesos is very reasonable. Cenote Samula is in the same complex. Separate 59 pesos but well worth seeing both.
Dzitnup is reviewed separately. This name comprises both cenotes.

244454176.name: Cool and calm place to spend a couple of hours
244454176.author: a TripAdvisor user
244454176.reviewBody: Swim in deep clear water, bats overhead and fish all around you.  We had it to ourselves for much of the time which made it extra special.

243489141.name: Excellent swim, great facilities
243489141.author: a TripAdvisor user
243489141.reviewBody:
Really loved this experience. There are people to rent life jackets and snorkles from if you want. Guy in carpark will mind your car for a tip (it was safe anyway). A guide book says that there are not changing facilities, this incorrect there were toilets to change. Staff were very nice.

Lots of small businesses wanting to rent equipment, sell food and trinkets. Please be respectful towards them, they are only trying to make a living. A polite 'no' will suffice if you are not interested. If you are, buy away.

Recommend this cenote

243358058.name: A singularly unique experience
243358058.author: a TripAdvisor user
243358058.reviewBody: I had never heard of cenotes before, so when we saw them all over the Yucatan peninsula we figured we must see what it\'s all about. Based on the area we were in (near Chichen Itza) and Tripadvisor, we decided on Xkeken as the one we would try. We were not disappointed. As soon as you being walking down into the cave you know you\'re in for something special. For reasons that are still unclear (we later got a vague story about government budget cuts), all of the lighting was out, so all we had was the flashlight from our cell phones and the sun that was coming in from an opening at the top. It was enough. A swimming hole with clear water and fish in a cavern, with bats flying around overhead? Definitely never done anything like it. The water was great - cold at first but you got used to it - and floating under the opening where the sun shone through was extremely relaxing. We were there with a literal busload of teenage girls, and when they all left, we had the place to ourselves. Magical. It was towards the end of the day and a worker turned the lights on and came down to start closing up. The two pictures are before and after - one without the lights, one with. If you\'re not a strong swimmer, I would definitely recommend the life vest that will get peddled to you on your way down.

242251548.name: Colonial Valladolid Cancun
242251548.author: a TripAdvisor user
242251548.reviewBody:
This is a brand new tour offered through Moon Palace. A all day tour + some but so worth it. Very comfortable tour bus with potty, air conditioning. The Tequila tour wasn't up to our liking as we've seen better.
When we stopped at Colonial Valladolid for the last shopping trip - we were told which public bathroom we could use. Yes some had seats and T.P. and some didn't. As long as you know what to expect and prepare for it all good.
 We were able to spend many hours swimming in the Cenote. A very nice lunch was prepared by the local Mayan's.
Our guide was so informative with history of the Mayan's culture, how they live and still hunt for the food.
We stopped in one little village and tried street food, he re assured us that the food was safe to eat..
You can use your Palace Resort credits for this tour.

240799603.name: So different from Samula cenote
240799603.author: a TripAdvisor user
240799603.reviewBody: More of a cave like feel than Samula cenote which is just across the way. You can see the bats flying across the light from the opening in the roof of the cave. I don\'t like swimming in dark water so stayed to the areas with light, but many more little black fish and it is a little colder than Samula. Vendors are a little pushy, I was surprised it wasn\'t busier for a weekend visit, but it means you get the place virtually to yourself.

237832478.name: Good cenote to swin near Valladolid
237832478.author: a TripAdvisor user
237832478.reviewBody: 7 km away from Valladolid, you can go ny taxi or rent a bike in your hostel( many have this service), I think by bike is more fun. of course it\u00b4s hot but you go to this cenote in a safe and shaded trail beside the road and nothing better than swin in a cool water when we feel hot.\nt costs 59 pesos to enter this cenote and there is another one beside, Samula( which we must pay another 59 pesos to enter ) these two cenotes are part of Dzinup cenotes and they worth a visit.

237573740.name: Meh
237573740.author: a TripAdvisor user
237573740.reviewBody: Did not love this place, such that\nI did not visit any other cenotes, which in retrospect was a mistake. Lucky me is returning to the Yucatan in February so I\'ll be able to rectify this.

237195439.name: Must see of this type
237195439.author: a TripAdvisor user
237195439.reviewBody: Ignore the outer stalls and entrance mumbo jumbo and enjoy this almost totally closed in cenote. It\'s not great for snorkeling but awesome for a swim and viewing the awesome cave features and bats! So many bats! And if you\'re freaked out by bats - really don\'t be...they just flutter overhead like big butterflies every now and then. There are little guppies in the water that will tickle your feet too if you stay still. They\'re harmless and just nipping at dead skin -- so awesome! Grab some cocos frios from the vendor closest to the stairwell. If you like to eat the coconut pulp ask for one \'con carne\' -- with beef -- to get a little bag of fresh coconut (and get chili and limon on it too).

232695516.name: Atmospheric!
232695516.author: a TripAdvisor user
232695516.reviewBody: Went early morning and apart from one other couple, had the place to myself which was magical. Hardly any artificial lighting when I was there which was for the better as the limited natural lighting gave the cenote a special feeling. There is a rope in the water that you can stand on which makes things easier, especially if you are not a great swimmer. Its a really special place with numerous cat fish swimming alongside you and bats flying overhead. Probably would be less special when busy so I would definitely recommend visiting early morning or later in the day.\nCost 40 peso for a taxi to get here from town and about 10 peso for a collectivo back (very hard to get a taxi back)

231862492.name: refreshing
231862492.author: a TripAdvisor user
231862492.reviewBody: nice, beautiful, easy access, not overpriced, fresh water. However, it is full of bats (what is expected for a closed cenote).

228275876.name: An experience to Remember
228275876.author: a TripAdvisor user
228275876.reviewBody: Never having been to an underground cenote before it was a truly memorable experience. And swimming in the cool, clear water surrounded by fish was amazing!\nSit still at the water\'s edge for a few minutes and the smaller fish nibble your toes. Humm!\nBut care must be taken. In some places the floor is very slippery, and it\'s easy to catch your head or other bits on the rocks.

227154304.name: gorgeous
227154304.author: a TripAdvisor user
227154304.reviewBody: Go there , not super crowded like the cenote close to Chichen. Very refreshing, etc. NO BUSES carrying hordes of tourists , only 10 people there, at least in the afternoon (we arrived at 3 30 PM). Color lights were off , or not working, which was fine.

224440023.name: beautiful - a nice bike ride from Vallodolid
224440023.author: a TripAdvisor user
224440023.reviewBody: We really enjoyed cycling here from Vallodolid. When we got here, we were told we couldn\'t enter as the electricity had gone, so we went to cenote Samula next door first, which I think may be even more beautiful. After an hour or so at cenote samula, swimming amongst the catfish and getting a free pedicure from the tiny fish, the electricity came back on and we were able to visit this one too. The one beam of light creates a magical effect on the water, the water is cool and clean, and the bats add to the atmosphere.\n\nnb: there are changing facilities but no lockers - it wasn\'t really an issue though as you could leave your things within sight and there weren\'t many people there.

222531177.name: Swimming with bats
222531177.author: a TripAdvisor user
222531177.reviewBody: Very nice and refreshing swim. A bit crowded. Photogenic! Will you accept young guy to give you a guiding help? Most of the way from the ticket boot to the cave is self explanatory, but maybe you\'ll get it there faster by following the boy who is versed in ways to walk through hanging shirts and dresses that are offered on the way to the entrance.

221620416.name: Kids loved it!
221620416.author: a TripAdvisor user
221620416.reviewBody: This was my kids\' (ages 15, 13 & 11) favorite part of our 10 day trip through the Yucatan.  As the photos show, it\'s a spectacular place to swim, and the water is so refreshing! My husband and I were thrown a bit by the whole setup, as the last time we swam in a cenote it was really just a hole in the ground, accessed via rope ladder.  When we pulled up to Xkeken I thought we\'d arrived at a pool club, with the ticket window, changing rooms, and vendors lining the walkway to the steps.  It was also pretty crowded inside (though more people seemed to be out of the water than in it), but most appeared to be locals, so it felt festive and fun rather than touristy.  Most of the other people also wore life jackets, but we definitely didn\'t need them.  There are ropes to stand on under water and its a short swim to any of the edges.  It\'s a fun, easy way to cool off after a day at the ruins, and there\'s cheap, yummy Yucatecan food served in a restaurant right outside, so you can make a nice day of it.

221404866.name: Amazing!
221404866.author: a TripAdvisor user
221404866.reviewBody: The beauty of this place will take your breath away.The water is a bit chilly but so worth it. Don\'t miss it.

218542379.name: GORGEOUS
218542379.author: a TripAdvisor user
218542379.reviewBody: I learned to dive here. The water is fresh, and the sunlight coming in from the top is incredible. Little catfish will swim around you. There are ropes in the water for you to stand on. Water is deep, dive-able obviously. \n\nFresh coconuts are sold outside, along with other types of local foods.

214770512.name: A beautiful refreshing underground swimming hole.
214770512.author: a TripAdvisor user
214770512.reviewBody: The cenote is well lit by artificial lighting and a very small hole in the roof, which allows a lance of sunlight to pierce the darkness. The water is azure and turquoise and there are small catfish swimming around you.

214761613.name: This is a must go
214761613.author: a TripAdvisor user
214761613.reviewBody: you have 2 shocking cenotes in one location, this is a postcard place and you can swimm, both have fish, in one of them fishes exfoliate your feet. very safe for children to swimm, you can rent life vest in case your kids need.

214755126.name: Beautiful & refreshing
214755126.author: a TripAdvisor user
214755126.reviewBody: We went to Xkeken on a warm afternoon during our stay in Valladolid. The cenote is beautiful and peaceful. Nice little walk between trees with the sounds of birds till you reach the entrance of the cenote. The water was great, very refreshing. Really nice experience. Entrance fee is 59 pesos, free for children. Parking is free.

214426714.name: Beautiful place to swim
214426714.author: a TripAdvisor user
214426714.reviewBody: Really well organised Cenote, there are very clean bathrooms and changing rooms and for those that aren\'t confident swimmers you can easily rent lifejackets. Inside the Cenote we saw a lot of bats!, the water was crystal clear so could also see lots of fish swimming around.The rays of light coming through gave the place a truly magical feel.

213036738.name: What an Experience!
213036738.author: a TripAdvisor user
213036738.reviewBody: We visited this cenote independently in the morning and were extremely lucky to have it to ourselves to swim in for a short while. It is extremely beautiful and very peaceful. This visit was a real highlight of our holiday and we will remember it forever.

211366890.name: fish, bats and people
211366890.author: a TripAdvisor user
211366890.reviewBody: Pretty spectacular cenote, good for swimming. Try not to arrive at the same time as 3 coaches full of tourists. June is quiet so we didn\'t have a problem. The ceiling is covered in bats, the pool is full of fish, and the water is cool and clear. I assume the fish live off the bat guano, but don\'t let that put you off.

205068083.name: Great fun
205068083.author: a TripAdvisor user
205068083.reviewBody:
We took a taxi that would take us to the site, wait for us 30 minutes on site and then bring us back (all for 100 pesos). 
Entrance costs 59 pesos each.
The site itself is well organised with several bathroom facilities and loads of shops to buy souvenirs. 

The cave itself is very impressive and offers a great swim. 
I wouldn't really dedicate more than 45-60 minutes to this visit though. We did it in 30 minutes and it was absolutely sufficient.

Worth a visit

203988153.name: Lovely cenote
203988153.author: a TripAdvisor user
203988153.reviewBody: Great cenote which was cool on a very hot day. Steps down very slippy and not many places to stick your towel once you were down. But lovely to swim in.

201858044.name: Absolutely stunning!
201858044.author: a TripAdvisor user
201858044.reviewBody: We visited both cenotes at Dzitnup:  X\'Keken and Sak Muu Ja.  Both are utterly stunning!  We were very fortunate that we were able to enjoy X\'Keken for quite some time in peace and quiet by ourselves.  It was an "other-worldly"  experience to swim inside this natural cavern, sunlight streaming in through the hole in the chamber roof and no sound other than bats squeaking and water plashing as we swam.   We left to visit the second cenote when the screaming crowd of revelers arrived. Sak Muu Ja is far different but just as gorgeous.  We were amazed at the azure water smack in the centre: brilliant and so clear it looked only 3 feet deep!  We were alone for at least a half hour and when people arrived, it was one other couple and an awesome fella by the name of Mike from NYC who were all happy to just enjoy the peace and beauty of the cenote.  The only downside was forgetting our camera -we both thought the other had it!  Postcards for sale for a dollar with many truly stunning images saved the day.  We took a taxi from Vallodolid to Dzitnup for $6.00 (USD) and the trip back cost $8.50 (USD) because the driver said we were going further than the main plaza.  Still well worth it!  The cost of entering the cenotes is minimal for what you see and experience.  There are lots of vendors but all are polite and gracious when told "No, gracias."  Highly recommend this side trip as a way of refreshing yourself on a hot, hot day and to just absorb some more of this earth\'s natural beauty!

200262310.name: Also known as Dzitnup
200262310.author: a TripAdvisor user
200262310.reviewBody: Wonderful cenote to swim in. the shaft of light that stabs the water is a delight to swim through. The neighbouring Samoula is also well worth the visit, and tends to get less visitors. Come early, that should be the rule for all cenotes, and you can enjoy the magical place to yourselves.

199826164.name: Refreshing
199826164.author: a TripAdvisor user
199826164.reviewBody: This cenote is small but refreshing. My husband and I got there around 10 am and the vendors were just getting started. We basically were the only ones there, barring a small Mexican family. You cannot do much in the cenote - there are no cliffs for diving or rope swings - but despite its small size it\'s very serene and different then some of the other open cenotes due to its almost closed off ceiling. There is only a small opening at the hop that lets in light making it a bit ominous. The water is cool but felt great after a hot day in the sun. We didn\'t stay long as there isn\'t much to do, but still worth a visit - just come early!

198464155.name: My, how things have changed.
198464155.author: a TripAdvisor user
198464155.reviewBody: This is a great spot. The whole place is magical. to swim in such pristine blue water is a real treat. A handful of years ago it was about 25 pesos for whoever entered. The attraction was the cenote. Now it is 59 pesos and has a bit of a circus feel. There are more diversions and hawkers than ever. They now have a palapa to set up under. I believe there was  some type of slide for the kiddies as well. The area was clean, but falling apart in spots. What I must say with the most scorn is the price nationals pay and the price foreigners pay. We have seen it from time to time in the last 9 months as we travel in mexico and central america. I could not justify this practice for a foreign visitor in my country, so this review loses points for charging me double. It is baseless. The fee to enter is not much, but the line for being charged double for being a foreigner has to be drawn. What\'s next, being charged double at a supermarket? Why not?

197207459.name: So blue
197207459.author: a TripAdvisor user
197207459.reviewBody: The water is so blue and refreshing. Entrance fee is 57 pesos and you can visis neighboring cenote Samula which cost also 57 pesos but Xkeken is much nicer!\ndont miss it!

196325115.name: Refreshing!
196325115.author: a TripAdvisor user
196325115.reviewBody: I\'m not sure what a few people are talking about in regards to colored lights flashing around here.  We didnt experience any of that, the cave was in its natural state and was awesome, only a small hole on top letting in sunlight, you could see lots of little cat fish swimming around and the stalactites and stalagmites.  Yes there were some bats--it is a cave.  They are hardly noticeable and are up on the ceiling.  They dont bother you at all, its like theyre not even there.  It is day time afterall, theyre sleeping.  The waters cold but not too cold and it feels great after a hot day exploring.  We were there in the middle of the afternoon with a tour group, but besides us there werent many other people there, didnt have a crowded feel.  The people who say there arent changing facilities are wrong, there are actually 2 areas for changing, one up front and one near the entrance to the cave.

195845117.name: Despite the outside appearance, still the way we remember cenotes
195845117.author: a TripAdvisor user
195845117.reviewBody: If you come early or late, you can still find a cenote here the way it used to be - with lots of fish nibbling your toes, and this one, is especially beautiful because of the light hole at the top and the amazing stalagmites and stalactites. \nJust try to avoid middle of the day crowds- the parking lots sure looks a bit scary\nThe water seems to stay clean because of a weak current.

195706323.name: Perfect activity to cool down after a morning of visits
195706323.author: a TripAdvisor user
195706323.reviewBody:
There are two cenotes. The one you see on the pics with the root going down is the Samula one. 

There are changing rooms but no lockers. It seems to be fine to leave your stuff on the platform in the Cenote but for peace of mind I wished I'd take my lock with me to lock my bag to the railings. 

The water is very clear and at a perfect temperature. Refreshing but not freezing. 

There are quite a few vendors but not overwhelmingly so and it is convenient if you aren't a great swimmer as they sell floating jackets.

195671514.name: probably the best cenote we visited
195671514.author: a TripAdvisor user
195671514.reviewBody: We visited three cenotes while in the Yucatan (Gran Cenote near Tulum, Ikil near Chichen Itza, and this one) and enjoyed this one the most. It was the cheapest (59 pesos/person), least crowded (maybe 20 people), and was very cool with a large cave with clear blue refreshing water to swim in as well as a hole allowing a beam of sunlight to come in. Just a very cool experience overall. Very clean restrooms at the ticketing area and overall good clean facilities. Seemed slightly more off the beaten path than the others and well worth it.

193389061.name: Absolutely magical
193389061.author: a TripAdvisor user
193389061.reviewBody: Small changing room, then a path through trees down to a small cave opening. \u00a0Beyond the cave opening is a steep flight of steps leading down into an enormous round cavern, perhaps 100 feet diameter and a similar height, \u00a0lit by a small opening in the roof and numerous blue and green lights dotted around the sides. \u00a0From the roof hangs stalactites, including a huge formation the size of a van in one corner, and roots from the trees above. \u00a0In the floor of the cavern is a deep pool of crystal-clear water that is chilly but fine for swimming in. \u00a0Sit on the waters edge where tiny fish nibble your feet, hands and legs, while larger black catfish, some up to ten inches long, swim in a shoal in the deeper water but keep clear of the swimmers. \u00a0Hang around at closing time.  The ripples on the water eventually peter out until it is smooth as a billiard table while the fish, sensing too, perhaps, that it is closing time, go into stasis. \u00a0And all around is the almost imperceptible \'drip-drip\' of water from the tree roots and stalactites, and the chirping and rustling of the bats hanging from the rock above. \u00a0A truly magical experience.

193278097.name: you in for a refreshing dip in a nice athmosphere?
193278097.author: a TripAdvisor user
193278097.reviewBody: go swim this cenotes! its like cave swimming, with a hole in the roof that lets in a magical sunbeam. the water feels cold first. but 20min. swim is well doable. and dont mind the small fish, they are super kind to have for company! :)

192783620.name: Extraordinary experince
192783620.author: a TripAdvisor user
192783620.reviewBody: Swimming in an underground cave with one little window to the outside world, amongst stalactites. Probably best to avoid high days and holidays though as above ground it is a bit of craft stall infested tourist attraction.

191365391.name: Wonderful!
191365391.author: a TripAdvisor user
191365391.reviewBody: In excellent conditions, with its own "internal climate", perfect for swimming! The atmosphere is magic.

188120598.name: Check it out!
188120598.author: a TripAdvisor user
188120598.reviewBody: We had this huge cenote all to ourselves.  A short bike ride away from the center of Valladolid late in the afternoon was a perfect get away to nature.  After descending a very steep stairway down into the cave you can swim across the cenote and perch atop a huge bolder to look up at the daylight above and let tiny pedicure fish clean up your toes.  Too ticklish at first but I got used to it and my feet felt great afterwards.

187898527.name: Xkeken Cenote
187898527.author: a TripAdvisor user
187898527.reviewBody: Unique cenote inside a cave with cathedral-like ceiling. Excellent for swimming. The one misgiving I have is the absence of showers - with so many bats doing their business as they hang from the ceiling, it would have been nice to rinse off :-)

186796550.name: Something different
186796550.author: a TripAdvisor user
186796550.reviewBody: This cenote has a more commercial set-up than I\'d expected (I\'d been told it was rustic...it\'s not), but it\'s well laid-out and has decent, if simple, changing rooms, which was good as it was raining on the day that we went.  It cost 57 pesos to get in and there is a garden area which looked well kept, but due to the rain, we couldn\'t really appreciate it.  \nThe cenote itself is big inside, and lit with coloured lights, which was a bit cheesy, but enabled us to see the little fish swimming around us in the crystal clear water.  Definitely worth a visit, but if you suffer from claustrophobia, might not be the place for you despite the size, as you are underground (there are other cenotes in the area which are apparently more open and with more natural daylight.

183213563.name: Excellent cenote
183213563.author: a TripAdvisor user
183213563.reviewBody: Crystal clear water + underground and in a cave = awesomeness\n\nAll I can say is, how amazing is that?

176553609.name: Lovely Experience
176553609.author: a TripAdvisor user
176553609.reviewBody: The cenote is very beautiful and there were fishes swimming in it. Many people did not like the colored lights but I guess it made it unique. It is wide enough and although there were other people swimming in it, wasn\'t too crowded. Overall, worth a stop

175172643.name: Swimming underground
175172643.author: a TripAdvisor user
175172643.reviewBody:
We took a cab both ways for 70 pesos (each way), and didn't mind the food vendors at all - you can get something to eat right after.  The xkeken cenote is in a cave with a tiny hole above letting in light.  There are also lights in the water, allowing you to see the depth, which appeared to be at least 25 feet.  There are numerous small fish (look like catfish) and bats in the ceiling, if that bothers you.

It is very slippery - was glad to have rubber soled shoes, and some liked having swim shoes for the rocky bottom.  Otherwise was a surreal experience; we went around 230 on a weekday, and there were maybe a dozen people there.  Note that you can rent a mask and float for 20 pesos for a man inside the cave.

NOTE: there are two cenotes, one on each side of the road as you come in from Valladolid.  thew ticket booth for both is on the right side; you have to go there and pay the fee (about 50 pesos) even if you only plan on swimming in the xkeken cenote (which is the one on the left side).

175085532.name: Nice but crowded, preferred Samula
175085532.author: a TripAdvisor user
175085532.reviewBody: Very busy in the afternoon (should have gone at a different time). Coloured lights in the cenotes. Nice modern changing rooms. Neighbouring Samula was actually much nicer in which, sitting on the \'island\' in the middle, you could have the dead skin nibbled delicately off your feet by the tiny fish!

173814145.name: lovely
173814145.author: a TripAdvisor user
173814145.reviewBody: Great time here and the other cenote. We went at 930am and were the only ones in there which was great. Only word of caution is beware of some of the people selling outside. We got lifecycles from one and he didn\'t give change, then tred to tell us we had been longer than an hour after 20 minutes and finally wouldn\'t let us use the jacket for the second cenote nearby unless we left our passports or bank cards with him obviously we didn\'t do that! Other than the people selling outside the cenote s are lovely.

168443035.name: Worth a stop
168443035.author: a TripAdvisor user
168443035.reviewBody: This cenote is underground: a large pool with stalactites hanging from the overhead rocks and a hole in the rock \'ceiling\' where sunlight shines down into the water. Many people were swimming when we visited and it was very peaceful & rather otherworldly. Caution: there\'s a steep and sometimes slippery stairway down to the pool, but it\'s well worth the descent.

167729061.name: Amazing but commercialized
167729061.author: a TripAdvisor user
167729061.reviewBody: Lots of people in the afternoon so I recommend going first thing in the morning. We took a cab from town, it was cheap. Stop beside the train tracks on the way and get a picture of the jungle down the tracks - really cool.

164293695.name: Tourist trap
164293695.author: a TripAdvisor user
164293695.reviewBody: If your a traveller run for the hills this cenote has been transformed into a Disney attraction cables line the walls and a horrid array of lights change colour every few minutes. The formations are OK but the development of the cave really takes away from the experience. There are many other far superior cenotes in the region without then tour bus hordes. On then other hand if your a package tourist from Cancun or on cruise ship you will likely love the place for all it\'s tackiness

163817751.name: Went late did it in 45 mins
163817751.author: a TripAdvisor user
163817751.reviewBody:
Ended up arriving at 3:30pm thinking we would have lots of time to go round until 5:30 but unfortunately site was due to close at 4:30. Good news was we were allowed in for free at 3:50pm. 

We hired a guide for $400mx it worth every penny as he gave us a whistle stop tour of sites. I know many people would prefer to take a long time appreciating each aspect of the heritage site, and I definitely could have, but the lack of time really concentrated the experience and left us wanting even more.

There was only two of us and the guide and it meant we got a really private experience. He showed so many amazing things from the engravings to the amazing acoustics of the site. Make sure to stand in front of the steps of the castila (so your back is facing towards the cenote) then clap your hands! Amazingly the sound the echoes back is that of a bird call, truly amazing site. 

Would love to go back, much more than a box ticking event but make sure you get a guide and go in a small group.

162525664.name: Very nice cenote
162525664.author: a TripAdvisor user
162525664.reviewBody: This cenote is close to Dzitnup cenote and also a little bigger. It\'s worthing checking out both. I would recommend to go by taxi. Apparently the same price like a colectivo. My friend and I were the only ones taking a swim. Outside the cenote there were 3 people making the best empanadas I ever had. We were watching them preparing and cooking them.

161797427.name: A different kind of swim!
161797427.author: a TripAdvisor user
161797427.reviewBody:
For only 56 pesos this is definitely worth a look. 
We cycled from Valladolid (only 7km) and arrived late morning. We were lucky that we were the only people there when we arrived, it probably wouldn't have the same feel with a coach-load of tourists!

I'd recommend cycling; it's a flat easy ride and makes the dip even more refreshing.

161222391.name: Wonderful... despite the colored lights
161222391.author: a TripAdvisor user
161222391.reviewBody: It\'s unfortunate one must walk through concrete pathways and shops to get to  natural beauty, but the clear and cool water quickly washes away the disdain for human order.  Go before noon to enjoy it without the crowds.

161058647.name: Unique experience
161058647.author: a TripAdvisor user
161058647.reviewBody: Underground, with stalagmites and colored lights. Changing area. Easily reachable by car or bike. Must be seen if in the Valladolid area. Swimming in a cenote is something that must be done in the area and this is one of the very top ones.

161030765.name: When going before the tour buses arrive, it is a super cave
161030765.author: a TripAdvisor user
161030765.reviewBody:
This is a very nice cenote. It is 7 km from valladolid so easy to come by with a bike in the morning. The entrance (56 mex) is in a large complex, where also another comparable cenote is. There are clean toilets but no showers. You can eat and there are many people around selling stuff in the afternoon. Clearly, a lot of tour buses pass by from 1 pm on as we noticed when leaving, but in the morning you have paradise for yourself. There are no lockers, but there is no problem taking your stuff into the cave in the morning. 
The cave is really beautiful and we liked the changing colors. The water is very clear and warm enough to stay in for a long time. Cool fish swim around and will clean your feet if you like. There are ropes to assist children etc in the water and due to the whole in the roof, you get nice light effects while watching the bats and fish. We stayed more than an hour and enjoyed it a lot. 

One of the better cenotes, but avoid by any cost the buses full of american cancun-tourists...

160353868.name: CAVE
160353868.author: a TripAdvisor user
160353868.reviewBody: It was interesting, but being a dusty cave with lots of stairs did not appeal to me. We were there at a very hot time and walking in such high heat was difficult.

157476468.name: Beautiful cenote--strange lighting
157476468.author: a TripAdvisor user
157476468.reviewBody: For context, we went on a Sunday afternoon and this was the only cenote we went to.  Crowds were minimal.  Vendor density and pushiness was low (with Chichen Itza being high-high on that scale).  Beautiful formation with clear water and several thick ropes to provide a rest from swimming and invite exploration.  Lighting is on the dim side but appropiate.  Two recommendations:  1) Why the lights keep changing color is puzzling and unfortunate:  it\'s a natural wonder, not a disco.  2) A locker would have been nice vs having to have someone stay out to play security guard.

156673919.name: Worth a Quick Detour
156673919.author: a TripAdvisor user
156673919.reviewBody: It\'s only a short walk from the main square, so why not take a look. Yes, there are better ones, little or no facilities for changing/swimming. So don\'t go swimming, just go and take a quick look.

156431421.name: Beautiful cenote, but busy with tourists
156431421.author: a TripAdvisor user
156431421.reviewBody:
This is a beautiful cenote as you can see from the photos people have uploaded, however it was fairly busy.

Most cenotes are open air, X'Keken has a roof with just a small hole in the top where the sunlight comes through.  The cenote itself has lights under the water and ropes to hold on to (which not all cenotes have), which made it a little less scary!

It's definitely worth visiting as it is unique, however there are others that are a lot quieter if you're just after a swim in a cenote.

155911278.name: My only trip to a cenote -  I was not disappointed.
155911278.author: a TripAdvisor user
155911278.reviewBody: The cavern was easy to climb into but be wary of slippery sections.  Once inside the view is delightful.  The water is quite clear and if you are lucky a beam of sunlight will be shining down into the depths.  Just off the road from Chichen Itza to Valladolid this is a good stop before lunch in the town.

153942921.name: Unbelievable Cenote
153942921.author: a TripAdvisor user
153942921.reviewBody: This is a total underground cenote and a fascinating sight. Located just outside Valladolid, it is easily accessed by cab. Entrance fee of apprx. 6$ US

153826765.name: Beautiful hideaway
153826765.author: a TripAdvisor user
153826765.reviewBody: First time to a cenote and glad we chose this one.  There was no crowd and it\'s beautiful inside.  Water was very cold but hubby swam in it and it had a lot of fish.

151785060.name: Underground pool in cave - okay but could be skipped
151785060.author: a TripAdvisor user
151785060.reviewBody:
We visted this cenote because it is staglemites and was easily accessible.

It is okay and kind of cool but costs $7 per person.

It is interesting that people used these for water sources and lived around them. There are lots throughout and if you wnat t visit a cenote there are plenty - some above ground and others in caves like this one.

151060745.name: Fantastic
151060745.author: a TripAdvisor user
151060745.reviewBody:
This is a real Wow place.  So beautiful to see.  

If you have little ones, make sure you bring life jackets, unless they are strong swimmers.  There are large and clean washrooms on site, where it would be suitable to change into your bathing suit.

A taxi from town costs 60 pesos each way.

149693786.name: Extraordinary Natural Wonder
149693786.author: a TripAdvisor user
149693786.reviewBody:
Traveling through the Yucatan peninsula, Cenotes are unique natural phenomenons. The Xkeken Cenote, located only about 8 kilometers from the main Zocalo of Valladolid, is unsurpassed in it's natural beauty. Xkeken is managed by the State of Yucatan and well organized, with easy access and plenty of free parking.

Come early and bring your camera...many people will begin to show up. we visited on a Sunday, but were fortunate to be the first to arrive, wonderful solitude. Without question, wear you bathing suit and take few valuables, for there are no security arrangements for personal belongings, but don't let this deter you. 

The photos you see of Xkeken do not do the natural beauty justice. Plan on swimming in cool, refreshing water. If you take some very calm time and allow the many,very small fish to nibble at your feet you will experience a unique sensation

149577107.name: Special, beautiful, and refreshing
149577107.author: a TripAdvisor user
149577107.reviewBody: My family and I drove here on the way back to Playa del Carmen from Chichen Itza.  It was a beautiful place that felt very special.  The lighting gave it a magical feel.  It was extremely refreshing to swim in the water, and helped break up the long drive back from Chichen Itza.  Swimming among the stalactites and the roots hanging down from the ceiling was a very unique experience.  It was not very crowded when we were there so it still retained much of its mystique.  I would definitely recommend coming here on the way back from Chichen Itza if you have rented a private car.

147391274.name: Very cool !
147391274.author: a TripAdvisor user
147391274.reviewBody: Went in November. I guess that\'s before the busy season picks up. We rented bikes in town. It was a longer ride than the maps make it out to be but worth it. These were mh first cenotes. Amazingly beautiful. The little fish nibble at your feet in the smaller one and the bigger cenote felt more like a cave. It was a little pricey and the maze of vendors was odd. Overall a good place to visit. Recommend going early.

145459255.name: Small but fun to visit
145459255.author: a TripAdvisor user
145459255.reviewBody:
Surprisingly small under ground cenote that was pricey and involved a meandering walk through numerous vendors before you actually got access.  But swimming is possible and the colorful lighting, although slightly dramatic, was pretty fun.  Definitely would not recommend visiting if there is a big crown.  My friend and I went in during the low season and alongside a small group of tourists that arrived by bus and this was fine, but knowing how small the cenote is, I am glad there weren't any additional people.

Price of admittance was strangely high, but it is conveniently located near Valladolid.

Don't trust google or other map services in terms of driving here.  Take the main highway toward Merida and look carefully for the turn off sign.  Or ask a local for directions.  If you do use a map service, it will direct you directly to Valladolid's very scenic waste dump/burning area, not the cenote.

143190130.name: Very cool
143190130.author: a TripAdvisor user
143190130.reviewBody:
I loved these Cenotes - very cheap to get into and great to swim in. 

If you're not a very confident swimmer, there are ropes around the pool that you can stand on, so that you don't have to swim. You can also sit on rocks in the shallow areas. 

They even have the little fish that eat all your dead skin!

142229689.name: Xkeken Stunning and Breathtaking
142229689.author: a TripAdvisor user
142229689.reviewBody: We adored this Cenote.We had been to another one a few years ago near Coba,which was open and in the daylight but this one within the cave setting and the lighting was beautiful and looked stunning.A beautiful cold swim after the heat of the day visiting Chichen itza.There are a lot of steps down to it and thet do get slippy.Not suitable for anyone in a wheel chair or have difficulty walking. There are toilets and changing facilities but no lockers and we put our clothes on our tour bus.Lovely Lovely Cenote well worth a visit

138720222.name: Very nice but a bit expensive
138720222.author: a TripAdvisor user
138720222.reviewBody: You have to take a taxi (50 pesos) or a colectivo (25-30 pesos) to go there, but it\u00b4s nice and refreshing. There is another cenote on the other side of the street, but you have to pay for it too (54 pesos).

132485014.name: Incredible!
132485014.author: a TripAdvisor user
132485014.reviewBody: We went to Xkeken and Samula cenotes on a 22km loop bike ride. It was an all round incredible experience. We were there around 10:30-12pm and we had both places to ourselves...well before the tourist buses arrived. Samula has an incredible tree root dangling down through a hole and Xkeken has a huge stalacmite and a little series of caves which you can explore. We took torches and saw loads of bats! A very unique site, a must do on a trip to Valladolid.

130656345.name: Stunning
130656345.author: a TripAdvisor user
130656345.reviewBody: We actually visited the Samula Cenote across the road from Xkeken. There is a central parking lot where you can but tickets for either cenote. They both cost the same ($52 pesos per person). Samula was stunning. There is a hole in the ceiling where an old tree has grown it roots down towards the water. The water itself is crystal clear and cool - very refreshing for a swim. There are hundreds of tiny birds that nest in the ceiling between the stalactites and small catfish that swim in the clear waters. Truly beautiful and worth a visit. Its only a few minutes drive from Valladolid

130652451.name: can\'t miss it...
130652451.author: a TripAdvisor user
130652451.reviewBody: if you are near Valladolid, Yucatan. We took a taxi cab from Valladolid and spend practically the afternoon in the Cenote. The beam of light is awesome...

128448068.name: Early bird
128448068.author: a TripAdvisor user
128448068.reviewBody: Beautiful cenote, got there around 9:00 am - first one there, had the place to ourselves. It\'s the perfect setting to really enjoy such natural beauty, pristine water and a sense of being back in time.

126741557.name: Goergeous cave and cenote - bring your swimsuit
126741557.author: a TripAdvisor user
126741557.reviewBody: Wish I had known to bring a swimsuit, but alas, we could only explore.  It was gorgeous - not a lot of people, lights that change colors, and there are a few caverns to explore (watch your head).  Very interesting.  The legend of X\'Keken is that the Mayans were chasing a pig which disappeared.  When the eventually found its trail, there was water, which led them to the cenote.

126174462.name: Worth the Visit
126174462.author: a TripAdvisor user
126174462.reviewBody: Very interesting and spectacular cenote, bring your swimsuit.\nWater is super soft due to the rain going through the lime superstructure.

125530034.name: Great experience, excellent stairs.
125530034.author: a TripAdvisor user
125530034.reviewBody: beautiful underground lake in a cavern, with an opening for the sunshine.   Water was not cold, just right and everything was very clean.

124939620.name: Stunning
124939620.author: a TripAdvisor user
124939620.reviewBody: A beautiful cenote just 4 km west of Valladolid. We went with a friend of ours who is a Mexican nation and were not disappointed. The place is beautiful. the water is refreshing and the place wasn\'t crowded. There are numerous fish and fantastic natural structures in this cenote. Put it on your list if you are traveling the Yucatan. We spent 26 days in the peninsula and can;t wait to return. This is a must do if you are in the area.

124217868.name: Amazing Cave
124217868.author: a TripAdvisor user
124217868.reviewBody: We visited the Cenote of X Keken on a sunny afternoon. The sunlight entering into the cave and the crystal clear water invite for swimming.

123716655.name: amazing place
123716655.author: a TripAdvisor user
123716655.reviewBody: totally amazing , we went to swim but the weather was cold so we just saw the place, the water is extemely clean and look so nice ans fresh for summer!

122850770.name: Must see and experience!
122850770.author: a TripAdvisor user
122850770.reviewBody: When you ask to go to Cenote Dzitnup, you arrive to two different cenotes.  These 2 cenotes are collectively known as Cenote Dzitnup by locals and tourists alike.  Xkeken Cenote and Cenote Samula are both worth the trip.  You have to pay for each cenote separately.  Water temperature is cool for the most part.  It is a natural beauty that is a must see!

121621646.name: Good place for an eerie swim
121621646.author: a TripAdvisor user
121621646.reviewBody: There are change rooms there and guys around to watch your stuff (although you can see it while you swim). Also snorkeling gear to rent if you want. Better choice for swimming than Samula.

121474427.name: not well run
121474427.author: a TripAdvisor user
121474427.reviewBody: you disappear like Alice into the cenote with nowhere to change and clamber over rocks to swim. but it is great to drift under these ancient calcium forms.\n

121303554.name: Journey to the center of the earth
121303554.author: a TripAdvisor user
121303554.reviewBody: A few kilometers west of Vallodolid is Cenote Xkeken.  After paying the entrance fee (about 50 pesos per person), you walk down a short flight of steps into a cavern with a crystal pool.  It is lit by a hole at the top of the cavern, about 50 feet above you.  There are stalactites hanging from the roof.  If you brought your swimsuit (and you should), you can go for a quick swin in the cold clear waters.  I felt some little fishes nibbling on my leg, but it was fun, not scary.  My wife was initially scared of going in and swimming, but later said it was lots of fun and she felt braver for going in.  (Of course, there are also little four year old children in the water with you.)  It felt like we were in Jules Verne\'s Journey to the Center of the Earth. Quite cool.

116660636.name: Best place near Valladolid to beat the heat
116660636.author: a TripAdvisor user
116660636.reviewBody: This cenote is incredible. You descend into a massive cavern complete with stalactites and roots that creep towards the water from the ceiling. A small opening at the top is all that allows natural light to enter, so artificial lights have been placed on the walls. Small black fish swim around but stay clear of the humans. \n\nThe entry fee was $52 pesos for extranjeros (non natives) and $27 for nationals, they let our 4 year old in free. In the cenote there are locals who will watch your things and have life vests available, no fee, they work on tips.

675588840.name: Absolute magic. A truly beloved place.
675588840.author: a TripAdvisor user
675588840.reviewBody:
What an amazing place!! I visited Zazil Tunich with my boyfriend and our friend for the after dark tour with a Mayan dinner experience. The land is pure magic at night and the wildlife is orchestral. Even though we haven’t had the morning experience, I highly recommend the evening one! The staff here are all super sweet and the cenote is owned and operated by the family who lead the tours and have painstaking designed and preserved the land with love you can feel. 

We drove from Tulum (1.5 hrs) and it was totally worth it — Everything was perfect from the moment we arrived. We were greeted by Oma at the entrance, and she took us through the land very mindfully, making sure our needs were met knowing that we had a long drive and that we were comfortable while dinner was prepared (vegan friendly options available). 

When we finished our delicious outdoor candlelit meal Oma began the tour. Her English is quite good and she’s very knowledgeable and clearly has a deep connection to the cenote. She took us through every detail of the cenote and playfully answered our questions and lead us down the lit path into the depths of the cenote. By the water we were initiated in a traditional Mayan ceremony followed by a 20 minute swim, having been blessed by the gods.

The cenote itself is a marvel and the immersive experience is so special. Oma taught us a lot about Mayan history, from the mythology to the language to the ancient use of cenotes — it was a peek into life in a different world. Every step of the journey feels ritualistic and designed with great care. The family is so sweet and we hope this cenote is loved by many more to come.

674226814.name: A very special place. Magical.
674226814.author: a TripAdvisor user
674226814.reviewBody:
We visited this place as part of our trip back from chicken itza. We had the place to our selves there was about 25 to 30 in our group , our guide was very knowledgeable about the history and spiritual side of this place. After a good lunch of chicken and rice with plenty of homemade lemonade we were led down steep steps deep under ground. As soon  as you enter in you get a magical feeling. Our group was gathered together around an alter for a Mayan blessing by a shaman. Once finished he gathered the newlyweds in front of us and then gave them a special blessing. The whole experience was moving and special. 
We then descended the slippery steps into the cold refreshing water. The shafts of light coming down through the holes in the ceiling brought a aura down into the water. After about 20 to 30 mins swim we ascended back into day light. 
The whole experience was magical and a refreshing swim after the swealtering heat of the day. 
A must see place...

671891721.name: Most Beautiful Cenote in Yucatan
671891721.author: a TripAdvisor user
671891721.reviewBody: This place is a "Wow" from the minute you arrive.   The place is just 30 minutes from Valladolid, easy to find, just behind the Mayan town of Yalcoba.  The entrance includes a delicious meal with chicken, beans, and rice. There is a lady making tortillas and the owners have drinks like beers, sodas, and wine for sale.   The facilities and services provided are clean and comfortable. There are showers(mandatory to wash chemicals and sweat before swimming). The cenote is amazing, it\'s about 70 feet underground but water is crystal clear and shallow.   A Mayan priest or Chaman is waiting for us to give us a blessing before touching the sacred water.  One of the most beautiful places I have ever seen.

667438513.name: It was unforgettable magical experience.
667438513.author: a TripAdvisor user
667438513.reviewBody: I visited here with my 7-yr old son during on April 15, 2019.\nThis cenote was exceptionally quiet and sacred. Manuel, our guide was very professional and kind. He is very knowledgeable with Mayan history & culture.  If Ik-kil is leisure-oriented one, this cenote is more like very sacred & pristine one. Very inspiring and spiritual space you can never forget. I strongly recommend this if you are interested in adventure and cenotes. At the end of tour, you are able to swim there, too!

666450839.name: A Beautiful and Special Place
666450839.author: a TripAdvisor user
666450839.reviewBody:
Porque se que los duenos leen TripAdvisor: Gracias Armando y su equipo. Me dio un noche perfecto.

I booked my experience at Zazil Tunich on a whim because of the good reviews. Transport to/from the property, a cenote tour and swim, and dinner cost 600 pesos, which is more than fair. Also, even though I was the only one who booked on the night I went, they honored my reservation, so my experience was private. I almost felt guilty that I was making everyone work just for me, but every staff member was lovely! Also, even though I booked only a few hours in advance, the owner was responsive in arranging my ride and he accepted Paypal. 

He picked me up himself because their driver was off that day. He was personable, a safe and good driver, and gave me a lot of info about the cenote and Mexico in general.

Upon arrival, I was led to clean bathrooms, nice lockers and changing rooms. I put on my bathing suite and headed out with Manuel, who proved to be an excellent tour guide in both Spanish and English.He told me a lot about the geology of the cenote, the history of the property, the area's history and Maya culture as we decended each level down. Towards the bottom, we stopped and a Maya priest gave a very nice blessing. Then, I was left to swim alone for 30 minutes in the most beautiful place I have ever seen. It was just me, some little black catfish and bats, and the peace and beauty. After I was done, Manuel came back and let me change, and then led me to a dinner set up by the fire outside. Julio was a great waiter and served me chips and dips, a main course of pollo pibil, and a marzipan. The food was delicious (especially the lemonade and handmade tortillas) and I got to play with a cute cat. When I was ready, I was driven back to my hotel.

Overall, this is a totally special and unique experience and you should not miss it!

663993148.name: TUI trip
663993148.author: a TripAdvisor user
663993148.reviewBody: This was part of our Chichen Itza trip. We stopped here for lunch which was OK but nothing special. The Cenote is beautiful and nice and cool. We were all blessed by  a Shaman then you could swim in the lovely clear water. My wife and I just had a paddle. We then saw them making chocolate from cocoa beans.

662593404.name: magical
662593404.author: a TripAdvisor user
662593404.reviewBody: i did the 3pm private tour and to my surprise I was the only one on the tour. I was left alone in the beautiful cave with the bats, to float around and decompress. I bought my tickets on their website but noticed that the same entry fee I paid was more on other sites so I\'m not sure why that is. It was just the basic entry fee. It\'s a great place to cool off on a hot day and all around spectacular.

661853703.name: A TRUE WONDER OF THE WORLD
661853703.author: a TripAdvisor user
661853703.reviewBody: Words almost escape me in describing how beautiful this cenote is.  We were all speechless at how pristine and stunning this cenote is. The grounds are very well kept and our guide was amazing. We met the owner who was a very pleasant gentleman as well. Don\'t miss this place.

658623835.name: Stunningly beautiful, very accommodating
658623835.author: a TripAdvisor user
658623835.reviewBody: We made a booking error but the management and tour guide quickly accommodated us and gave us a fantastic experience. The whole experience is truly beautiful, highly recommend.

650836389.name: well worth going to see
650836389.author: a TripAdvisor user
650836389.reviewBody: visited a couple of cenotes while in cancun but this one was well worth going to . and for those who don\'t swim its only about 4......5 foot deep a nice experience. but the water is cold  lol. the staff where very helpful and had a nice meal there.

650597441.name: A Gem. Very accommodating, friendly, welcoming, and an overall great experience.
650597441.author: a TripAdvisor user
650597441.reviewBody:
Sorry for the late review.
My wife and I travelled to Valladolid in January of 2018 and this was our first stop. We booked a dinner and tour at 8 pm. I was so amazed that we were the only ones there but Pedro, Armando and his family made us feel like honoured guests. I really felt like we were putting them out, as it was just my wife and I, but they did not make us feel any less important. 
The tour was amazing! Pedro had a wealth of knowledge about the local flora and Mayan History.  We loved the entire experience which started with a traditional Mayan meal. My wife and I really enjoyed the beverage (described to us as a lime/Mexican spinach drink) and the food was excellent! 
We were brought down into the cenote with a prayer ceremony by their shaman as we entered 'Xibalba' (the Mayan underworld) and Pedro told the ancient story of the hero twins. It was a very immersive experience and Pedro is an excellent story teller.    
The grounds are absolutely amazing and you can tell a lot of care and attention to detail went into it its construction. The Cenote is absolutely gorgeous! 
This was one of the highlights of our last trip to Mexico and if you are travelling to the area, it is a must see! My wife and I cannot recommend it enough! Thank you to Armando, Pedro and his family for welcoming us to their little piece of paradise and making us feel so welcome!

649888018.name: Day trip
649888018.author: a TripAdvisor user
649888018.reviewBody: After leaving chichen itza went in to a little village Mayan village a very interesting then we went to the cinote. Well we had a lovely meal if you wanted any why you have to pay for that separately but we did.then after that was shown to were the changing rooms where they went down into the cinote. We were blessed by a mayon person then we were allowed to go for a swim the water was fresh which means cold had a great day

648828781.name: If closed, try Cenote Xcanahaltun
648828781.author: a TripAdvisor user
648828781.reviewBody: We tried to do a drop-in visit to Tunich in the afternoon after visiting Ek\u2019Balam by motorscooter, but it Apparently doesn\u2019t open until 3 pm (the signs were very poor) and we ended up at Cenote Xcanahaltun on the same road about 1 km away. This was a lovely Cenote with its own beautiful stalagmites and a tour bus had just left, so we had it to ourselves. Cost was 100 MXN per person. Quite a beautiful place.

643635926.name: Highlight of our Yucatan Trip
643635926.author: a TripAdvisor user
643635926.reviewBody: We took the 6 pm tour that includes a traditional Mayan dinner and all agreed it was a highlight of our ten-day Yucatan trip. Our kids (10 and 12) loved it. The cenote is truly magical, with excellent lighting and well-built stairs and pathways. As our tour guide led us down into the cavern, he explained the discovery and history of the cenote, and its religious significance to the Mayans. It was very interesting, to us as well as the kids. Then we got to swim for half an hour. The water was cold but not unbearably so, and shallow enough to wade. Dinner afterward was delicious to all, even our son who is a picky eater. Would definitely recommend! Make sure you reserve in advance.

640764642.name: Highly recommended
640764642.author: a TripAdvisor user
640764642.reviewBody: Very nice tour with welcoming guide (Manuel). We visited other cenotes before but this was a complete new and perfect experience!

633603029.name: Zazil Tunish where Mayan culture and nature become a beautiful gem
633603029.author: a TripAdvisor user
633603029.reviewBody: We love  Zazil Tunish For all the human and natural wonders that offer, in this ancient sea bed as hard as steel,  nature show it forces, by giving us a luxurious tropical jungle, among this green sea you will find  the tranquillity in a cozy and beautifully design caba\u00f1as and delicious traditional mayan food served on the jungle garden or on a magnificent palm roofed rancho, catered by Mar\u00eda en her charming mayan team. on a lovely hand crafted pottery dishes, the food is complemented by fresh fruits, caf\u00e9 de olla and sweet bread from a neighborhood mayan town. Meanwhile 14 Mts. below the surface of this tropical paradise there will be a awaiting you nature craft at it best, the most beautiful cenote among thousands in the region of Yucat\u00e1n, and the infra world of the Mayan Culture,  before  beginning this sacred journey you wil be blessed by a Mayan priest  who then will ask  El Aluk through his prayers, to let us live a Mayan cosmology ritual, The entrance to Xibalba the underworld, this is traditionally held by the mayan in a cave or cenote, you will live the nine spiritual passages of this guided sacred tour ritual with the chants of the priest and the aroma of his Copal Incense, through this nature wonder that has lasted over 300,000 thousands years. After you will be invite to swim and relax, in the cristal clear waters of the Cenote  Zuzil Tunish this will complete your purification journey before re entering the historical and luxurious grounds of Zazil Tunish. \nAfterward Maria and Armando the designated keepers by the mayan and owners  Zazil Tunish and their mayan working team will offer you the mayan sacred beverage the chocolate and many other natural food and products to your delight. To us Zazil Tunish is a gem of the Yucatan tourist path. \nEnjoy!

618056482.name: Magical.
618056482.author: a TripAdvisor user
618056482.reviewBody:
Visited here yesterday, (18th September).
Allowed to go into tbe water after a blessing fom the Shaman.
The Cenote is simply beautiful..   water ice cold but once in tbe water the cold doesn't seem to matter anymore.
Perfect end to s perfect day.
Would definitely recommend a visit here.

615584014.name: Absolut fantastic!
615584014.author: a TripAdvisor user
615584014.reviewBody: We went there on the afternoon and were with another couple the only one. It\u2019s a very beautiful place to visit! So well organised! We enjoyed it a lot, especially because it was raining all day, so it\u2019s a good trip for a rainy afternoon!

610678212.name: An enchanted evening!
610678212.author: a TripAdvisor user
610678212.reviewBody: I reserved the 6p tour of Zazil Tunich, with an add-on of transport from/to my hotel in Valladolid, and dinner at the site. Everything exceeded expectation!  An attentive bilingual guide brought our small group of mostly adults to the cave where a shaman\'s blessing added to the mystical tranquility of the experience. The cave is magnificent with stalagmites and stalactites, and the cenote waters are clear blue and inviting. We exited the cave after sunset, following our guide beneath the canopy of trees to a thached roof dining room. There we enjoyed a dinner of regional foods that were perfectly prepared and graciouly served before returning with our driver over the moonlit backroads to Valladolid.

598036421.name: Amazing experience, you have to go there
598036421.author: a TripAdvisor user
598036421.reviewBody:
We visited Zazil Tunich today and were alone during the visit (groups of max. 20 people). Manuel was a great guide, we learned a lot about the history of the Mayas and could attend a Maya Ceremony in the Cenote (which is breathtaking).
Then we had a delicious diner with specialties from the region.
2 hours for 400 pesos/person (diner included), it was worth every dime.

We highly recommend it!

597037872.name: Magical experience in jungle
597037872.author: a TripAdvisor user
597037872.reviewBody:
If you are looking for a magical experience away from the the usual tourists, this is the place for you. 

This cenote is amazing! The afternoon tours are private, making the experience unique and individualized. The cenote itself is vast and spectacular. 

Manuel the guide is knowledgeable and caring. He guides you on the tour and teaches along the way. 

My son’s favorite part was the the Mayan blessing in the cenote. It was a spiritual experience, making us feel like welcome guests in a sacred place.

After the tour, you are left in the cenote to swim and explore by yourself. 

Once you are done swimming you can opt in to a traditional dish on site. This particular day they served chicken pibil style. It was some of the best food we had on the trip! 

Overall this cenote experience was the best one we have had. The family atmosphere and the great service it top notch. 

Thank you Armando for inviting us into your magical home!

Megen

587263537.name: Romantic Private Time
587263537.author: a TripAdvisor user
587263537.reviewBody:
My wife and I arrived for the 3:00 tour and were surprised to see two tour buses in the parking lot.  We were hoping to have a more private experience and were happy to see that they were just leaving.  They accept bus tours in the morning and early afternoon and then the small tours in the afternoon.  We were the only two on the tour and after hearing about the history of the area and doing the tour of the cavern area, we arrived at the water level.  The guide told us to jump on in and that he would be back in 45 minutes.  He left us alone to marvel in the quiet beauty of the Cenote.

The water is cool but you get used to it quickly and after about 15 minutes of exploring the area in the water, we just sat down next to one of the underwater lights and talked and enjoyed the scenery.  We would suggest wearing water socks since the bottom of the Cenote has some larger rocks and partial stalagmites poking up from the bottom.  

After finishing the tour, we had dinner and it was one of the best meals that we had that week.  The ground Pumpkin Seed and tomato salsa and chips was delicious and the main course of Pollo Pibil (cooked underground) was extremely tender and moist and served with vegetables, rice and refried beans. We drank the entire pitcher of Limeade that was served and the desert was quite a treat.

We were there about three hours and the entire cost was only $35 for the two of us.  We ended up tipping the guide and servers almost that much because of the service and experience.  Though this is out of the way to get to, it is definitely, DEFINITELY worth the effort!  A wonderful experience!!!

573245686.name: A Must-Visit Near Valladolid!
573245686.author: a TripAdvisor user
573245686.reviewBody: This was one of our favorite experiences from our week in the Yucatan. Even before visiting, we were so impressed with the personal communication we had with Armando. He was great about responding to our questions over email. We decided to pay for the all-inclusive experience (transportation to and from the cenote, cenote tour, and dinner) for 600 pesos a piece, and it was well worth it! We were picked up right outside our hotel and driven the very complicated route to Zazil Tunich. We were given a tour (in Spanish because we wanted the practice) that lasted about 20 minutes. It ended with a traditional Mayan ceremony (5 minutes) and a 20 minute swim in the cenote. Gorgeous! And a bonus: we were the only ones on our tour! Following the swim, we changed clothes and ate a delicious 3-course Yucatecan dinner of chips and sikil pak, chicken pibil, rice, and beans, and marzipan for dessert. We stayed after dinner for fun conversation with the family. They were very warm and inviting! If you only have time for one cenote during your trip, we highly recommend Zazil Tunich!

569674520.name: One of the best Cenotes
569674520.author: a TripAdvisor user
569674520.reviewBody: We took a group of 8 and all agreed it was spectacular.  We have been to many Cenotes in the Yucatan and this Cenote is one of the best.  Huge cave, excellent wood paths and platforms (no slippery rocks), beautiful lighting, excellent guide.  Even a Mayan ceremony to bless our entry.  The entry grounds are very nice and well maintained.  It is a bit out of the way but well worth the trip.

568712053.name: Excellent underground cenote with Mayan dinner
568712053.author: a TripAdvisor user
568712053.reviewBody: This underground cenote is superb and we were the only ones there so had the whole place to ourselves. The guide Pedro is very passionate about the place and gave us detailed explanation. WE also had wonderful Mayan dinner ( chicken cooked cocina pibil style and amazing pumpkin seed dip called sikil pak)

558427223.name: Beautiful and Personal Cenote Experience
558427223.author: a TripAdvisor user
558427223.reviewBody: Booked an evening visit for our family of four and were joined with one other family, eight people total. The tour was nice if a bit long (Armando is terrific but a talker!) and the swim a bit short. But -- gorgeous, large cavern cenote and you enjoy the swim and a shaman blessing, plus a delicious Mayan meal afterward. We had other cenotes we ended up enjoying a bit more and were a much better value, but Zazil Tunich is gorgeous and personal and a beautiful intro to Mayan culture. Thank you!

554872119.name: Great Tour
554872119.author: a TripAdvisor user
554872119.reviewBody: As all but one of the reviews have stated, this is a lovely cenote. Off the beaten track, but a stunning single chamber cave, thoughtfully made accessible to the public. They had to tunnel down into it to make the entrance and exit, by hand. It is beautifully lit, the water is no colder than any other enclosed cenote I\'ve visited (a lot) and the place is very atmospheric. Our guide was excellent and gave a clear explanation of both the creation of the place and of Mayan traditions surrounding it. We had a shaman bless us and give us permission to enter, which could easily have been turned into a lot of fakery, but he was dressed in normal clothes, and went through the ceremony with none of the nonsense you can get with these sorts of things. We had the meal at the end, which was good, and an added bonus for us with the night time visit was the lack of light pollution and and fantastically clear night sky. Coming from the UK, I\'ve rarely seen so many stars. It also has the largest stalactite yet discovered in the Yucatan, and is different from any other cenote visit I\'ve made.

554593405.name: Awe-inspiring!! Largest cavern we have ever been in with beautiful lighting and water!
554593405.author: a TripAdvisor user
554593405.reviewBody: We could not believe our eyes when we first walked down the tunneled stone stairway down into this cenote...just WOW!  Giant wooded walkway around the entire edge of cavern with the largest stalachtites we have ever seen.  The lighting is totally cool, including the blue, clean water for swimming in.  The walkway ends in a huge "beachlike" flat setting, and enters the cenote.  Large enough for weddings and events. Probably the best cenote around, don\'t miss it.  If you are visiting Chichen-Itza be sure to stop here, it is along the way.  This experience made the entire trip to the Yucatan worth it. The taxis from Vallodolid will take a trip here for approximately 10 USD and wait for you to bring you back.  We went twice, and I can\'t wait to go again.  They have a brand new restaurant serving traditional Mayan food which was delicious!!  The staff is as friendly as they come..

550320627.name: Fabulous!
550320627.author: a TripAdvisor user
550320627.reviewBody:
We booked the trip through the website, and chose the 6 pm tour with a meal, 1400 pesos for four, there didn’t seem to be children prices. This was one of the highlights of our fourth trip to Yucatán, and both 4.5 and 6 y o loved it.

As we were driving in the increasingly middle-of-nowhere road with wild vegetation on the sides, it got completely dark, and I though this started to look unsafe and a bit scary. My fears were relieved when we saw a nice parking lot (the parking lot entrance is 300 yards past the actual location on Google maps, with blue flags) and three other cars pulled in at the same time as us. 

There were two guided groups, Spanish-speaking and ours, English speaking, the latter was us and one more person. In total there were close to 20 tourists, on the day after Christmas. 

It’s a good idea to bring a long-sleeved top at this time of the year, as air was 18 C by the time we left. Also, it’s not worth bringing a snorkel in the cave - not much to see - or anything else besides a swimsuit (wetsuit is perfect if you have one) and a towel. 

The tour included getting two shaman blessings, to enter the cave, and then later to swim in the water. First there is walking in the cave admiring cave formations and listening to the Mayan stories, maybe 45 min. Then we got in the water and swam- it was shallow, you could stand half of the time. Apparently, the water level varies and it was on a low side. The water was on the cold side but everyone except one person got in, the last person exited the water after 40 min of swimming.

The dinner that followed was fantastic - perhaps the best we’ve had on our 11-day trip. Simply AMAZING food - not your typical contemporary Mexican tacos but genuine Mayan flavors - marinated in achiote and not at all spicy (unless you add sauce). The freshly made tortillas were incredible. We couldn’t help but ask for half of the recipes which the family gladly shared. We appreciated the fact that the owners checked with us if it’s ok to give dessert to kids before doing so (we were making tortillas while kids were still at the table). Making tortillas was fun, and even our 4.5 and 6 y o made their own, and loved eating their creations.

Apart from our own enjoyment, it is important to note what this family did for the cenote. For them, it is like a living being that breathes and lives, and they care for it to support and extend its life. Thank you for preserving and sharing this beautiful gem!

547507738.name: First cenote visit
547507738.author: a TripAdvisor user
547507738.reviewBody: After having visited the Chichen Itza, our TUI guide brought us to this cenote. First we got a local lunch which tasted alright and after that it was time to visit the cenote which is basically a water well under the ground. It\u2019s not very good to see on the pictures but it actually looks quite nice. You get a small blessing from a local in it but after a few minutes you have seen it all. You can swim there too but the water is ice cold. It was fun to see once but it\u2019s not a must when visiting Mexico.

542218548.name: Fantastic!  Highly recommend a visit.
542218548.author: a TripAdvisor user
542218548.reviewBody:
Not sure which we liked more, visiting Zazil Tunich or interacting with the family that owns and runs it.    

I arranged a tour with the owner via Whattsap.  His English is not the best, but we managed and when there's any difficulties, his daughter helps him out.

We arrived by prearranged transfer.  150 pesos per person.  We went at night and it's a little bit hard to find, so I'm glad we had a transfer.
