There are changing rooms and toilets onsite which is good, and a gift shop full of the usual tourist rubbish. A peacock struts about freely which again is a nice picture opportunity. It\u2019s not the best cenote by a long way, but you\u2019ll have a pleasant experience, perhaps not that authentic though!

670279622.name: Nice pics, crowded, dirty
670279622.author: a TripAdvisor user
670279622.reviewBody: The cenote itself is beautiful, the effect you get and the pictures you can take, are fantastic, however there are couple BUTS... Its touristy, many buses come and after 11 there is one tour after another with the maya shows taking place every hour... water is not the cleanest as well... is it worth going for the cenote itself? NO... For the pictures? Well, if you get lucky you can take some very nice ones,... so YES

663552281.name: WOW
663552281.author: a TripAdvisor user
663552281.reviewBody: This was my third cenote and I was again amazed at how different each one is, and this one no less fascinating.  We swam about a bit and watched and listened to the drums, singing, dancing and smug stick cleansing activity happening on the platform.  We were on an all inclusive tour and did not have to pay admission.  Otherwise, you need to take $1 for a life vest if you want to get into the water, otherwise you can put your feet in.  Wonderful experience.  There is a changing area, restrooms and a gift shop.

657469546.name: Ok...
657469546.author: a TripAdvisor user
657469546.reviewBody: Nice cenote, too touristy and too expensive (120P) for what you get! Water smells and is not clear. We took a taxi to the cenote (60P). A mayan show started at 10am on the plattform and was built up from 9.45am\nWe arrived early (9am) and it was not very busy. When the people started to build up we thought that it\'s only for 10 minutes, but the show was for 3 hours!! So it was not possible to make a picture without mayans or swimming people... really bad expierience

656435764.name: Beautiful
656435764.author: a TripAdvisor user
656435764.reviewBody: We reached there around 4:15 as our last stop on the Chichen Itza. Not very crowded so it was very nice and quiet.  \n\nIt has beautiful limestone formations with a skylight in the middle that gave it a mysterious glow. The water was cool but nice after a really hot day.

655903179.name: Impressive
655903179.author: a TripAdvisor user
655903179.reviewBody: We were there early, so we were really lucky. We got to have the whole cenote to ourselves and we loved it! Later when we were leaving, there was a huge crowd of people waiting to get in, so that must not have been so nice.

655521776.name: Very cool place to visit
655521776.author: a TripAdvisor user
655521776.reviewBody: We came with a tour group and there were other tour groups.  We had about 30 minutes to look around the shop.  Things didn\'t have prices.  Then we went to swim in the cenote.  We had to pay to rent a life vest if you were going swimming, $30 pesos or $2 American each.  There wasn\'t anyone in the cenote to enforce the life vest rule.  We shared ours with someone who didn\'t have cash to rent one. There were 3 people performing on the platform.  The water was cool but it was a really cool experience swimming in it.  There were fish swimming also.  There are a lot of steps.  With our tour we got a buffet lunch with 2 free drinks which were good.  I definitely recommend a visit.

654576070.name: Mystical.
654576070.author: a TripAdvisor user
654576070.reviewBody: There\'s that mystical feeling when you enter the cenote that you don\'t find anywhere else. We arrived early in the morning. It says on Internet that it opens at 9.00 but we were there at 8.30 and they let us in. We were in the first ones to enjoy the tranquility and peace of the place. The light coming through the rocks of the ceiling. It is stunning. And fab for the gram. The only thing is that stone area in the middle, even though it makes the place special and allows you to take unbeatable pictures, it didn\'t come naturally with the cenote and was a human touch. An advice, go early and enjoy the vibe.

651939099.name: picturesque, just avoid crowds!
651939099.author: a TripAdvisor user
651939099.reviewBody: Amazing rays of light come in on the stone platform makes for a beautiful picture and GREAT swim if you\'re alone in it (I was lucky to be with only my group), the cave formations are very impressive with right light.... sometimes the crowds take away but if you come near closing time or opening, you should miss most crowds~

646426187.name: Remarkable atmosphere
646426187.author: a TripAdvisor user
646426187.reviewBody: An incredibly mystical, atmospheric atmosphere, slightly contrived to provide the perfect photo opportunity, but no less beautiful for that!

644819811.name: Get there early
644819811.author: a TripAdvisor user
644819811.reviewBody: If you want that photo with the natural beam you need to wait until mid day, however, if you want the place for your self, arrive at door opening. Or pay extra for private time.

642793253.name: Its most picturesque cenote I had gone to!
642793253.author: a TripAdvisor user
642793253.reviewBody: This cenote site was loaded with tour buses upon my arrival, but there were a few at the cenote. Walking down to the cenote was a mystical experience and sighting the platform in the cenote was simply mind blowing.  There was a small opening in the ceiling of the cenote and it illuminated the turquoise water. It\u2019s the most picturesque and beautiful in every possible way of three cenotes I visited (Oxman, Zaci, and this one).  Apparently, there was a demonstrative Mayan ceremony in the cenote at around noon because there were three beautifully body painted Mayans walking out the cenote when I walked down to it.  One of them carried a dish of burning vegetation resembling sage but it had a distinctive smell.  I looked at the brick wall circling an opening before I walked down to the cenote cluelessly. It was the opening that brought the light to the cenote underneath.  It was spooky to think about people walking on the ground right above the cenote. There is a retailer and a cafe to browse.

642059951.name: Tranquil and mysterious place.
642059951.author: a TripAdvisor user
642059951.reviewBody: For me, this is the first cenote I have ever seen and it did have the wow factor. You go down some steps into a huge cavern and there are many rock formations.  The pool itself has a platform where people were enjoying taking photos but it was fairly quiet when I was there around 3.30pm \nI went in and for someone from temperate climate I did not find the water very cold. You have to wear a lifejacket which they provide for you. There are some catfish and those small fish they have at spas which nibble your feet which you can sit with at the cenotes edge. Lots of space to just sit and contemplate too.

638059603.name: Not good for swimming...
638059603.author: a TripAdvisor user
638059603.reviewBody: 120 pesos for entrance. Nice cenote but if you ask me not good for swimming. But you definitely should see that...

636284600.name: A little disappointing
636284600.author: a TripAdvisor user
636284600.reviewBody: I love cenotes and was looking forward to this but it was a little disappointing. It was very touristy, not peaceful like others I have gone to. There were quite a few people who were more interested in taking selfies. There was a show going on in the center of the cenote where a stage had been built. Loud drumming and music; not a bad show but I would rather have seen it outside. The objective was to get visitors to take pictures and give tips. One\'s picture was taken at the entrance. They told me it was for security but at the end, my picture was on a bottle of liquor for me to purchase if I wanted. First time visitors to Mexico and cenotes will like this place, but if you have been to many and want a more natural setting, this is not for you.

635120962.name: Not as good as you\'d expect.
635120962.author: a TripAdvisor user
635120962.reviewBody: It honestly looks waaay better in pictures. The fact that there is human interference in it (platform built and the water bed has some kind of tiles on it) made it less special being there.

633484320.name: Incredible Cenote for Taking Beautiful Photos!
633484320.author: a TripAdvisor user
633484320.reviewBody:
I had wanted to visit this cenote ever since I saw a photo on Instagram showing someone standing in the middle, below a glorious beam of light. It was too beautiful of a spot to pass up on this trip!

The cenote is located in Valladolid, about a 10-minute drive from the city centre. You can get there by taxi from the main ADO bus station for about MXN80-120 pesos (our guy charged us MXN120). On the way back, our taxi driver charged us only MXN60. We were coming in from Tulum after a long morning full of shooting along Tulum Beach. For those planning to visit from Tulum, I advise taking the ADO bus. It's super easy and costs MXN98 per person. I'm sure you can take the bus from other places, but I'm not sure how long it would take or what the costs are. When taking the bus, do allow yourself enough time (if visiting in the afternoon) to get there. Our bus ran a little slow and took just over 2 hours to arrive in Valladolid. After hopping in a cab, we ended up getting to the cenote around 4:15pm. I was under the impression that it closed at 5:00pm (my Google search informed me as such), so I was afraid we would only have an hour to take photos. But when we arrived the lady at the front told us we had until 6:00pm. I'm not sure if this is only on Saturday, so double check just to make sure before going. The entrance fee was MXN80 per person (cash only). Compared to a lot of really popular cenotes in Tulum, I found this to be pretty affordable.

If you want to enjoy the cenote without a lot of people around, I recommend going mid- to late afternoon. This way, you can avoid the large crowds from tour buses and even have the place to yourself. Plus, by that time, people have left because they're off to another activity/dinner and not many more will arrive because it's simply so close to closing. When we got there at 4:15 pm, we were legit the only tourists there. We entered into the cenote as two people were leaving and had the whole place alone for a good half hour (before a large group came). For photo purposes, we waited until they left and asked the security guard if we could spend some extra time (5 min) for some last photos and he kindly agreed. That's another thing - all the staff here are so friendly!

I do think you should be careful if you or anyone in your group has mobility issues. The steps may be steep for some and can get very slippery from all the water that people bring along with them while passing in/out.

The cenote itself is so beautiful and the water is so so clear. It really looks like something out of a movie. And you can even see lots of little catfish swimming around. It's so nice and can be really enjoyable if you go during down times so you're not fighting crowds. Although I'm happy we went at the time we did, we did have to make the trade off of not getting that beam of light shining through the top of the cenote. Had I had the time, i would've probably spent all day there to photograph it! Maybe next time ;)

This is definitely a must-see if you are in the area.

633418762.name: Wonderful cenote
633418762.author: a TripAdvisor user
633418762.reviewBody: Was exactly what expected. Plus no long lines or nothing. The place on the inside is just amazing, and th swim is great. Would recommend anytime.

629012721.name: Wow!
629012721.author: a TripAdvisor user
629012721.reviewBody: This cenote is not one that the regular tourist buses get to which is great! When we got there late int he afternoon, we had it all to ourselves which made fro some fantastic photos. this is a shallow cenote and very cold. there are also fish in which nibble your toes!

624834383.name: Magical!
624834383.author: a TripAdvisor user
624834383.reviewBody: One of the greatest places I\'ve ever been to, it\'s truly breathtaking. It probably helped that we arrived when there was no one else there but I would highly recommend regardless that you visit this cenote.

623970384.name: It is terrific place for photo
623970384.author: a TripAdvisor user
623970384.reviewBody: Well, there is not much to say about cenote  Suytun... for swimming it is not the best cenote in Yucatan but for photo , this is a terrific cenote

620042553.name: Great Place to Photograph
620042553.author: a TripAdvisor user
620042553.reviewBody: This is one of our favorite underground cenotes. The stalactite formations are quite impressive, and the platform of course, is a great place to take a photo. The best times to get the sun on the platform during late summer is around noon.

612927457.name: just... WOW!
612927457.author: a TripAdvisor user
612927457.reviewBody: We decided to stop off at Suytun cenote during a daytrip from Tulum to Valladolid, and are SO glad we did! It\'s the most incredible cenote - it is deep underground and once in, almost totally enclosed except for a circle in the roof throughout which sunlight (and rain!) comes through. It reminded me of the inside of a enormous spaceship, with stalactites of all sizes and mysterious caves around the central pool. The water is cold but crystal clear and full of catfish, and you can enter the water either from the edges or from an ancient platform that ends directly under the shaft of sunlight from above.  It\'s otherworldly, mysterious, and completely stunning - a must-see. I think it\'s also not very well-known - we were nearly the only people in there (about 4pm).

606368178.name: Good, but mostly too crowded
606368178.author: a TripAdvisor user
606368178.reviewBody: We tried to come here twice. First time at about 11:30 am. There were 6 coach busses and some cars on the parking area. So you can probably imagine how full it would be. We decided to go to Chich\u00e9n Itz\u00e1 and come back after that. At that time only 2 cars and one coach were there. It was about 3:30 pm, still many people for that place. We had to wait until about 5 pm to get some decent pictures. So if you want to go swimming, it is probably fine, but still not awesome as there are bigger and better cenotes where you can swim.\nIf you want to take some pictures better make sure to come early or before closing.

604751385.name: A beautiful and tranquil cenote
604751385.author: a TripAdvisor user
604751385.reviewBody: My boyfriend and I visited this cenote after seeing it in a music video (embarrassing confession) and I\u2019m SO glad we did. We read some information about it before and arrived around 12:30 after all the Chichen Itza tour buses were leaving and within about 45 minutes of being there we were the only ones. There were changing rooms with showers and life jackets for those who wanted to swim. The cenote was beautiful, very photogenic and lovely to swim in. Well worth a trip out of Valladolid

602381037.name: Suytun is a beautiful Tavern that is a sacred cenote
602381037.author: a TripAdvisor user
602381037.reviewBody:
Suytun is an amazing location in Cancun
Well worth the trip.  There are beautiful art and  craft
Mayan shops and at the end of the tour one gets a fantastic education of how the Mayan of this tour is coupled with viewing the Chichen Itza which is the one of the 7 wonders of the world.

Take the Cancun Bay tours, there are a couple of tour guides Victor an ex school teacher who communicates well and is a riot .  David is well versed with Mayan history and has to communicate an ancient civilization and their values.

586953901.name: I thought it was magical
586953901.author: a TripAdvisor user
586953901.reviewBody:
We took a bus day trip to Chichen itza, it stopped here first.
Wow, what a beauty...? nice cool water with little cat fishes. The scenery is magical!
 
The life vests are mandatory, I believe it was 30 pesos per person. If you have mobility issues its probably not a good place. The stairs going down and coming up are hard on the knees. 

Also the store is very pricey...if you are going to other stops after this one than wait. My daughter paid double what I did for a Mexican blanket at this stop.

581438625.name: Unforgettable place
581438625.author: a TripAdvisor user
581438625.reviewBody: There are many cenotes in Yucatan, must this one impressed me the most. The water is not super clean, and it is not super deep, but is almost completely underground with one small hole on the top. The game of the sunrays on the water surface is amazing! Really worth visiting!\nWe visited it a part of the one-day trip to Chichen Itza.

569587140.name: Morning in Valladoid
569587140.author: a TripAdvisor user
569587140.reviewBody: Amazing cenote near Valladoid. We arrived there early morning and were so lucky to have the place just for us ! If you are around the town you should definitely have a look ! it\'s also possible to swim.

559841301.name: A Mixed Experience
559841301.author: a TripAdvisor user
559841301.reviewBody:
Well this is a review of two halves, 

Our visit to this cenote was part of a full day organised by our hotel to Chichen Itza. This stop was one of two shorter stops (alongside our longer stop at the main attraction) during the day. 

I will start with the positives, the actual cenote was beautiful and unlike other critics I did not find the paving of the bottom or the main walking feature in the meddle of the venue to be off putting. It think this makes it easier for families (especially children and older relatives) to visit the venue. The water was very cold but incredibly clear/pure and it was excellent to be able to stand and marvel in the natural geography/geology  that had formed this excellent underwater canyon. 

Following walking down the steep steps (it is important to hold your children’s/older relatives hands at this point), you roughly need about 30-40 minutes to enjoy the scenery (and take plenty of photos) as well as swim. 

This venue also provides (into the price) a buffet lunch which consisted of salads, vegetables, tortilla filled wraps p, spaghetti and a range of deserts. You could eat as much as you liked and the quality of the food was good. The waiter /waitresses were friendly and there was a short Mexican dancing display to entertain guests. 

Now for the negatives... 

Like other reviews have highlighted a significant amount of effort by the owners are spent assertively/at time forcefully attempting to get you to purchase items. This starts  prior to getting to the venue when the tour guide informs you of the Mayan Birth certificate (400 Mexican Pesos) as well as the Necklace (900-2,000 Mexican Pesos). Also you have to walk through the gift shop prior to getting to the Cenote which is manned by what seemed like an army of salesmen/women who actively push the souvenirs. The quality of these could not be doubted but what was frustrating was the varied nature of the pricing of these items which seemed to be based on what the individual felt they could achieve. This view was confirmed by the fact the shop floor staff who ‘helped you choose’ having to inform the checkout staff of the selected items price.

There were no changing rooms for the cenote and we were informed to either change in the toilet or the jungle behind the cenote. Also it is mandatory to wear a life jacket when swimming in the cenote (even though the water is shallow and can be stood in at all times). What was more frustrating however, was that you had to pay extra for the life jacket which was not advertised. This was compounded by the fact that the individual who informed us of the need said the price was 20 Pesos whilst the other suggested it was actually 30.

The drinks in the inclusive buffet were not included in the price and the price ranged from £5-10 for soft drinks. 

Finally we were joined by a student from the Mayan village who gave us a free shot of a local drink and taught us the Mayan toasting tradition. This was interesting but it was  followed by giving us a bottle of the drink with our picture on. We were then asked to either hand the bottle back to the student or purchase the alcohol. We of course purchased it (for an expensive price), but this was a further clever way to charge tourists.

All in all I would certainly recommend visiting this beautiful location and chance to learn about the Mayan culture. However, just be prepared for the push to spend lots of money

552762043.name: Off the beaten path beauty
552762043.author: a TripAdvisor user
552762043.reviewBody: 2 cenotes here, one for viewing and the other is like a magical cathedral. We were lucky to get there after the crowds left (afternoon) and had it almost entirely to ourselves. Water is icy refreshing and the light inside the cenote is other worldly.

540123503.name: Magic
540123503.author: a TripAdvisor user
540123503.reviewBody: We stopped at this cenote on a journey from Valladolid to Tulum; we didn\u2019t come as part of a tour or group. After entry through the gift shop (don\u2019t bother, there\u2019s cheaper elsewhere), the changing facilities were clean and functional, then off to the cenote! Life jackets are required if swimming in the water, but not mandatory otherwise. After descending some fairly steep steps, we were inside the cavern and it was SPECTACULAR. Stalactites hung from the ceiling, and daylight streamed through in from above. The water was cold, but a thoroughly refreshing swim on a hot day!\n\nI\u2019d highly recommend a visit, and a swim.

516710597.name: Surreal!
516710597.author: a TripAdvisor user
516710597.reviewBody: I have traveled to this part of Mexico for over a decade and the last visit included several cenotes.  I am glad visitors are finally able to explore these surreal water filled caves.  They are all simply amazing to swim or just view.  I recommend swimming in the cold clear waters.  Besides, it is supposed to be good luck.

511694408.name: Great experience!
511694408.author: a TripAdvisor user
511694408.reviewBody: My family enjoyed swimming in the cenote. It\'s a little walk down to cenote. Water is cold so perfect on a hot day. Bring extra set of clothes and towels. There\'s bathroom for you to change and rinse up.

476831305.name: Cool-literally
476831305.author: a TripAdvisor user
476831305.reviewBody: This was an great addition to our Chichen Itza tour. We stopped here for lunch and walked through their store and had a swim in the cenote. It was kind of murky when we got there but we had a few tour buses worth of people there at the same time. It was just a great experience to do with my sons-swim in an underground lake in Mexico! Just a great memory. It was quite chilly, which you should anticipate when you think about it. We all stood, knee deep, looking at each other to see who\'d take the plunge first. It was glorious when you get in. The heat of the day at Chichen Itza made the chilly swim a distant memory quickly. \nIt was great.

472797388.name: Beautiful but ambushed
472797388.author: a TripAdvisor user
472797388.reviewBody: We arrived here through a tour company.  They forced tourists to go through their shop where they are selling over priced, commercialized products as handmade Mayan items.  I was fortunate enough to actually stop in a Mayan village 4 years ago when we did a tour of Tulum.  Those Mayans actually did have homemade jewelry and clothing that they sold which was nothing like what was being pushed down our throats.  Then we were forced to rent life jackets even though you could touch the bottom of the Cenote.  It just felt like we were being pressured for money the moment the bus doors opened.  That pressure was a very sad thing because the Cenote was so beautiful once you got down in to it.  The water was chilly but refreshing.  The sun shone through the opening in the ceiling down in to the water.  The ceilings has beautiful stalagmites.  The experience would have been so much better without the added pressure to spend money.

457888115.name: Vacations in Canc\u00fan
457888115.author: a TripAdvisor user
457888115.reviewBody: Hi, this was a very nice trip. If you want to swim, lifevests are mandatories. Trip from Canc\u00fan is like 2 hours to the Cenote. Then to Chichen Itza. Overall great experience.

450982020.name: Beautiful Cenote nice to visit
450982020.author: a TripAdvisor user
450982020.reviewBody: This cenote is beautiful, even it is looks nice is not the most attractive to swim, even though could be an amazing place for a meeting or ceremony. The cabanas looks amazing, with the pool and restaurant. Perfect for families.

448655340.name: Tourist trap visited as part of a trip to Chichen Itza
448655340.author: a TripAdvisor user
448655340.reviewBody:
Visited this Cenote on the way to Chichen Itza as part of a coach tour.
It is very much the stereotypical tourist trap (when visited as part of a tour) they try to sell you anything and everything, blessings from a Shamen, photos, silver pendants, expensive shop on site. For example the traditional blankets were on sale for 50 USD but I picked a similar one up from Chichen Itza for about 6 USD. We were unlucky enough to be served dinner here and there we got the hard sell again pestered for drinks and tips.
If you want to visit this attraction I think its best to go independently its inexpensive, if you go with a tour you get hassle hassle hassle.
Look at the photos decide if you want to go and maybe stop off as you are passing it on the road to Chichen Itza or Coba.

447822450.name: Amazing To See
447822450.author: a TripAdvisor user
447822450.reviewBody: If you are visiting the Valladolid area the this place is a must! Steep stairs but worth the climb.  Spectacular spot!

446621047.name: Wow!
446621047.author: a TripAdvisor user
446621047.reviewBody: This place is amazing! We had the chance to be here alon for 10-15 min, and it was so quiet and peacefull! Beautiful blue water, nice platform and amazing shapes of the stons!  From valladolid it cost us 70 pesos for taxi, to enter 50 per person, and 20 more for a lifejucket, which we didn\'t use because the water was cold, and for the way back you can find a taxi on the road for 15 pesos each!

439605401.name: Beautiful quiet cenote, cheap camping
439605401.author: a TripAdvisor user
439605401.reviewBody: We camped near the restaurant and had use of the showers, bathrooms and big pool. Friendly and helpful staff showed us to the nearby cenote which was completely deserted, an absolute to joy to have it to ourselves. Surroundings are beautiful, very calm and relaxing, however tour buses do use this place as a restaurant stop so could get much busier.

437173996.name: gorgeous place, not many people
437173996.author: a TripAdvisor user
437173996.reviewBody: We heard about this cenote from a friend. We arrived arounf noon, just when a small tour was leaving so we had the place mostly to ourselves. You have to go down a few flights of stairs, but as soon as you go into the cave/underground, it\'s so worth it.

435498102.name: Disappointing
435498102.author: a TripAdvisor user
435498102.reviewBody: What were they thinking when they decided to pave the bottom of the cenote and build an ugly feature in the middle ruining the natural beauty of the cave?! Visited all of the cenotes in the area around Valladolid and there is only one worth going to...cenote San Lorenzo oxman

417518369.name: Closest you can get to a Cenote deep underground
417518369.author: a TripAdvisor user
417518369.reviewBody: Really busy place, but a wonderful experience. Bring your swimsuit, and a camera that adjusts to dark light. Very safe for climbing down and up, just beautiful.

386199173.name: Nice cenotes and no crowds
386199173.author: a TripAdvisor user
386199173.reviewBody: There are two cenotes on this site, both similar, but we felt that nr. 1 was the better of the two. Both are full subterranean caverns with underground lake, stalactites etc. but in nr. 1 they have installed a stone walkway out to a platform in the middle of the lake under the light hole. This gives a whole different perspective for viewing the cavern. \nWe visited middle of the day and were the only people here but the site has various tourist facilities attached and there were lifejackets laid out as if a party of swimmers was expected. Perhaps this is a stop for tour buses after a day of sightseeing at the Mayan ruins, not sure.

385604200.name: Beautifully annoying
385604200.author: a TripAdvisor user
385604200.reviewBody:
I was in awe when I saw the cenote. I had never been to one before, so it was pretty amazing for me. You were able to take pictures and even swim in the water. 

The only annoying part were the vendors. I have a feeling the tour company and the vendors were working together. Prices were ridiculously high. $50 usd for two shot glasses...$15 usd for a magnate...I decided not to buy anything. When we got to chichen itza, I saw the same type of shot glass and magnates. 2 shot glasses for $5 and the same magnate for $1.

Our tour guide asked us not to buy anything at chichen itza because of some obscene reason...but most people on the tour bought at chichen itza instead.

The cenote was still beautiful!

361463945.name: Stunning!
361463945.author: a TripAdvisor user
361463945.reviewBody: I couldn\'t believe my eyes with such a beauty. We visited the Cenote with our three children, one is 6, 3 and 1. They all wanted to swim, including the baby. We took a tour from the hotel with David, he was so great! Our 6 and 3 yr old did the zip line, then the Cenote and then Villadolid. I was amazed with the pureness of this area, the treatment and humbleness from everyone, it was just great. I highly recommend it! By the way, we didn\'t see not one mosquito during this season.

357392884.name: Fun place to visit
357392884.author: a TripAdvisor user
357392884.reviewBody: Interesting cenote, great photo shots.  Has changing rooms, small snack bar with chips, soda, etc. Swimming in cenote is a fun experience, bring your own towels.

353561136.name: Nice, cold water
353561136.author: a TripAdvisor user
353561136.reviewBody: This cenote is not as beautiful as Ik Kil. It has a very small opening at the top so very little natural sunlight. The cenote is mostly lit with artificial lights and I think it takes away from the whole experience. It smells very dank and musty. The water however is very clear with lots of small fish. Life jackets are mandatory and yes you have to rent them. The changing rooms and bathrooms are very clean

348645343.name: One of the highlights of my life.
348645343.author: a TripAdvisor user
348645343.reviewBody: The whole day bus trip to Chitzen Itza & this cenote was too long, but descending down into this cenote and swimming in the clear, cool water was unbelievable.  Thinking of the Mayans who used these as holy places and the beauty surrounding you is nothing short of amazing.  I did struggle going back up all those steps, but it was well worth it.  I found it to be very peaceful.  Skip the bus trips and find a private tour.

341707765.name: Impressive cenote!
341707765.author: a TripAdvisor user
341707765.reviewBody:
I had only been to Ik Kil cenote before and I wanted to try something different. Needless to say that this was an awesome cenote!

It's different from Ik Kil because it's underground. You also cannot jump or dive into the water because it isn't as deep as Ik Kil. You must wear a life jacket to swim in the water regardless of how experienced you are.

I believe that there are more steps to get to Suytun which may not be as suitable for elderly or disabled people. I probably wouldn't recommend it if you have trouble with stairs.

However, this cenote is a must see! I totally love it there and it was an impressive experience.

340680635.name: Amazing!
340680635.author: a TripAdvisor user
340680635.reviewBody: Stopped here on our way back from chichen itza. It was the best part of our tour. Decending down into the cave was exciting and swimming in the refreshing water was one of my favorite parts of our excursion.

338964184.name: From a Hole in the Ground to an Underground Grotto
338964184.author: a TripAdvisor user
338964184.reviewBody: I\'m told that sometime more than five years ago Suytun Conote was discovered by a farmer who saw a hole in the ground. Putting his ear to the hole, he heard water. With dynamite, they opened the hole to reveal what you see today. We visited here on our Chichen itza tour. It\'s just a short distance from Valladolid, maybe a mile or two. We were offered a swim on this visit. I waited at the top of a very steep staircase while others, including my companion, descended to the platform below. They told me how beautiful the water was, that a hole in the top offered light, and there were fish in the water. At the time I didn\'t know the story. \nThe grounds are well maintained. A small cafe, which wasn\'t open, a gift shop with high priced souvenirs, but excellent quality, very clean toilets with soap, water and paper towels and on the grounds were peacocks, chicken, dogs. The peacocks wanted to eat my cookie, so be careful eating in front of them. This was the end of a very long day before heading back to Cancun. I\'m told there are perhaps 3,000 conotes in the Yucatan Peninsula. They keep finding more all the time.

336262484.name: Review of Cabin Rental Only
336262484.author: a TripAdvisor user
336262484.reviewBody: My in-laws are Mexican and I have visited other cenotes in the past. If you are coming here on a day trip with part of a tour, then yes a score of 4 or 5 is merited if you have never seen a cenote before. This is only a review of the services we received by renting a cabin on the property and staying a few days. By Mexican standards we paid a good price, however, they were short toilet paper and even towels for the rooms, (my Mexican family had brought both toilet paper and towels). There was no toilet seat in one of the rooms (we rented three cabins) which caused problems for my 86-year-old mother-in-law who uses a wheelchair. It is a common practice to remove toilet seats in public restrooms or some restaurants, but not when you rent a hotel room or a cabin. In the first room we had no AC, so they changed us to another room in which there was no antenna for the TV. They literally ran out of food at breakfast, but there was enough food put aside for the bus tours which arrived a couple of hours later. There was no bartender at night, so we were limited to beer, tequila shots or rum and coca. There was no wine of any kind. As is normal in Mexico we brought hammocks from home, but they were missing hooks with which to hang them. If you\'re from North America or Europe, you wouldn\'t normally expect them, but for a Mexican family this was not particularly cool. They closed the cenote at 5 p.m. as soon as the last bus tour was done. There was no music at night, even though they had speakers there for the daytime tourists. The staff were nice and did their very best to accommodate us, but we were left with the impression that this was a cash grab for the owners who made their money from the daytime bus tours.  Over all, I would suggest you go there to see the cenote which is worth it, but stay in a hotel in the pueblo, not on the property itself.

306143636.name: Excellent Cenote
306143636.author: a TripAdvisor user
306143636.reviewBody: We came here on a trip to Chichen Itza, the tour stops at the Cenote to allow you to do some shopping and then swim. You will need to rent a life jacket to swim and I would recommend bringing your own towel otherwise you will need to rent that as well. The Cenote is absolutely beautiful, is fairly shallow in most places and you can even see plenty of catfish. Great experience.

300600985.name: Gorgeous gorgeous gorgeous
300600985.author: a TripAdvisor user
300600985.reviewBody: My husband and I went to this Cenote as a part of a group tour. When you first get to the area, there are a few little stores selling Mayan related things: jewelry, stones, carvings, plates, etc. We bypassed these and went straight to the Cenote. You must rent a lifejacket to go swimming in the Cenote. You go down a steep staircase into the cave where the swimming hole is located. There is a large platform that has been constructed to take you towards the beam of light that shines down from the hole in the top of the cave. The water is a bit chilly, but not too bad. The Cenote is truly a stunning site to see. I highly recommend coming here.

280414289.name: Eerily beautiful!
280414289.author: a TripAdvisor user
280414289.reviewBody: A light shines from the ground above, illuminating the central stone platform. The water is cool and refreshing mineral blue, fish swim lazily around you. Dip your toes and let the little fish come near and nibble. Tap the water to bring curious catfish to the surface. Subterranean serenity!

269151042.name: Mayan culture lives on
269151042.author: a TripAdvisor user
269151042.reviewBody: We learned too late of the history and Mayan beliefs in swimming in the Cenotes.  It was beautiful inside with the sun-rays coming to rest on the water from above the Cenote opening.  The place was jammed with tourists of all ages.  Be careful on the steps, they are steep and not of equal heights.  Take your time both going down and coming up.  There is an unmarked landing almost at the turn to go down to the water that drops down quite steep.  Be sure and take a swim suit and towels to enjoy the pool.  Don\'t forget to shower before entering the pool.  Showers are available next to the women\'s and men\'s bathrooms.  There are stalactites reaching down from the top of the cavern.  It is quite a sight not left to the imagination, you must go in to experience the Cenote.  They have life jackets you can rent and they recommend everyone wear one.  There is one deep spot toward the back of the Cenote.  The steps lead down to a small landing where you get into the water.  These are spiritual waters and to be respected.

263105955.name: I think it\'s changed since I went 6 years ago!
263105955.author: a TripAdvisor user
263105955.reviewBody: My mom and I came across this cenote one day of our road trip through the Yucatan.  We were the only ones there that day. Actually, it seemed like we were the only ones there that year! It was do desolate and quiet, nearly creepy. We paid our dues and looked around all on our own.  Staying for about an hour, it was like being on the set of an Indiana Jones movie!  You walk down into the cenote and just stand on the little pillar stone in the middle.  We didn\u2019t swim, really, but did get our feet wet.  Lots of little black fish. I thought, \u201cgeez, I hope this cenote survives on the randomness of its location way out here\u201d, but it appears to be doing just fine from the reviews I\u2019ve seen!  I\u2019m glad, because it\u2019s truly one of a kind.

261612643.name: QUICK SWIM IN CRYSTAL CLEAR WATER
261612643.author: a TripAdvisor user
261612643.reviewBody: we took the tour to chitzen itza and stopped for lunch at Carretera Libre Valladolid at the cenote and after lunch we had a half hour to take a dip , it is about a hundred feet underground down a decent stairway , a bit tough getting back up after swimming , it was cool but not as bad as I expected , really clear water , with huge stalactites hanging above and the room about 400 feet across , very exhilarating and not long enough of a time to really enjoy but we enjoyed what time we had , there are lockers but you donot need them as there are bleacher type steps beside the pool to pile your belongings and the life jackets they rent are for poor swimmers , the lunch we had at the cafe at the cenote entance was a smorg and was good with a taste of mexico , but there was a lot of people with their hand out for tips , bring a lot of $1 dollar bills , there was a little entertainment with a boy and a girl dancing in mexican traditional garb , tip , margarita , tip , meal , tip , mayan warior with picture , tip , and the suevenier stand is way over priced , much cheaper on the grounds inside chitzen itza ,  if this review is helpful , please give me a vote

253563088.name: Too Much Selling...
253563088.author: a TripAdvisor user
253563088.reviewBody:
First of all, the cenote itself was quite nice.  We enjoyed the feeling of descending into the darkness of the cave and seeing the stalactites and stalagmites through the eerie green light.  The water was  lovely shades of blue, and a few people were swimming.  Too chilly for us, however.  Going up and down the rough hewn stone stairs would not be for everyone as they were rather jagged and irregular with a  rope hand rail to hold on to.

The area above ground where the hole to the cenote was located was fenced in and covered with grating.  This was understandable and acceptable except for all the garbage and debris lying within that area.

The bothersome part was the aggressive commercialism of the visit.  Just glancing at a piece of art for sale meant non-stop badgering by a salesperson.  Plus, we were told these items would be unique and a wonderful buy - not true as we saw nicer examples of the same items at more reasonable prices other places.  Two boys were painted as warriors for picture taking opportunities - for a price, of course.  Even a horse was on display with a tip jar by his side.  And, of course, in order to get to the cenote, visitors had to pass through the artisans' tent.

I feel sure there are more genuine cenote experiences to be had in this area.  We were part of a tour which went to this one, and we would not do that again.

252687840.name: Bucket list MUST! swim with a sunray shining on you in an Underground Cave!
252687840.author: a TripAdvisor user
252687840.reviewBody: On a Chichen Itza trip we stopped here and I was amazed.\nGot to swim with the fishes and had a sunbeam reflect on me and it was amazing!\nSurreal and bliss all rolled into one!

250989491.name: Okay
250989491.author: a TripAdvisor user
250989491.reviewBody: The cenote was pretty; however the vendors in the gift area were overly persistent and actually had higher prices on items that we saw later in the day at Chichen Itza (even after bargaining them down).  The stone steps down into the cenote are pretty steep but not too slick; however the areas inside the cenote can be a little slick so water shoes are a good idea.  They charge about $2 to rent a life jacket if you want to swim in the cenote (it\'s required if you want to swim).

248112294.name: It was OKAY.
248112294.author: a TripAdvisor user
248112294.reviewBody: It was only \'okay\' because we went to a different cenote from the day before (Aktun Chen cenote). It was nice, but it would\'ve been nicer if there were light in the bottom of the water to truly see the depth of the cenote. \n\nWe went here during the tour, and I cannot remember which company it was (my apologies). Water was clean, and facilities were clean. My bf said it was a nice dip after a long, humid day at Chichen Itza.

236340541.name: Eerily Exhilarating!
236340541.author: a TripAdvisor user
236340541.reviewBody: We stopped here on our way back from Chichen Itza on our bus tour. You climb down a flight of stone steps so be sure to wear aqua shoes. Beautiful cave interior. The water was a bit chilly with small black fish swimming about, but very refreshing to take a dip in. Going back up the staircase was a bit difficult as the steps are quite steep and there is only a rope to hold onto. Changing facilities were clean. Wished our tour would\'ve allowed for more time to enjoy this.

228859860.name: Very unique
228859860.author: a TripAdvisor user
228859860.reviewBody: We stopped here as part of our tour to Chichen Itza. It was a really neat thing to see. We did not bring our swimsuits, so we did not swim in it, but many others did. There is a bathroom where you can change into your swimsuit and it is suprisingly clean. I highly reccomend seeing a cenote if you are in Mexico.

211364674.name: Neat town
211364674.author: a TripAdvisor user
211364674.reviewBody: Nice central square, safe sort of atmosphere, not entirely distorted by tourism. Art in the town hall on the square worth a look if you are at a loose end (open till quite late).

207591109.name: Fun Cenote!
207591109.author: a TripAdvisor user
207591109.reviewBody: We stopped here on our way back from Chichen Itza. It was a very cool place! One of those once in a lifetime things to do. The water was super clear (very cold) and had fish in it. There are life jackets and other equipment if you\'d like, but we chose to go in without all of that. There was also a stand that sold food and drinks.

187916411.name: Nice cenote, but too much man-made changes
187916411.author: a TripAdvisor user
187916411.reviewBody: During my stay in Mexico, I\'ve visited several cenotes. Suytun was the biggest fully closed cenote I\'ve visited, and I was hoping to find a beautiful cenote. Instead, when you go downstairs, the first thing that struck my eye was the disgusting man-made peer going all the way to the middle of the cenote. This is so unnecessary. Also (I am pro nature conservation) there is no policy on float jackets, so people just put down their feet on the rocks where ever they can stand (the water has a max. debt of only 5 meter), which slowly destroys the underwater world. When I was there, there wasn\'t really anyone checking what the people were doing. But I\'ve noticed people using sun lotion upstairs and then going into the water, which again is a definite no-no to nature conservation. So yeah, I was kind of bummed out by all of this. The site itself is very clean and has good facilities though (showers, toilets, bar,..).

187486866.name: Beautiful!
187486866.author: a TripAdvisor user
187486866.reviewBody: The cenote is gorgeous, about 5 mi. out of Valladolid. You can take a taxi, but it wasn\'t as easy to get back (although not too difficult). I had the place to myself for awhile; it is a closed cenote definitely worth it.  Cost 50 pesos to enter, and 30 for a towel, I will return for sure. \nThey have ice cream and some snacks, and just stairs as it is a natural place. The people that owned it were very nice.

168226885.name: Serene & interesting cave swim
168226885.author: a TripAdvisor user
168226885.reviewBody:
The grounds include several changing areas and showers, along with a gaggle of pet geese and a sad female peacock in a cage.  There were stands for juices and coco frios, but they weren't open when we went - probably because it was rainy and nearly empty.  You walk a little ways to the back and descend down a stone stairway to the cenote.

Entering the cave, you see an enormous open space with stalagmites and stalactites and one hole in the ceiling allowing in some natural light.  It was absolutely silent, except for some water dripping and the occasional bird flying into the side passages.  Between the space and the silence, it had a very cool feel that was both peaceful and slightly spooky.

The cenote itself has a platform built into the middle of it, which I understand from pictures is the stage for some faux-Mayan rituals.  I'm glad there was nothing of the sort when we were there.  I jumped from the platform into the deeper water (there is a sign on the stairway showing the various depths), and it was refreshingly chilly.  I floated on my back for a while looking up at the stalactites, and it was incredibly serene.  The only wildlife were some small black fish with catfish-like feelers and the birds flying in and out of the cave.

The average rating is due primarily to the sheen of sunblock and human oils on the top of the water, which was very noticeable.  They clearly do not enforce their "shower before swimming" rule.  Instead of feeling refreshed after getting out of the water, I felt like I had a film of other people's used sunscreen.  Not that my skin was slippery or anything - it was just psychological.  I was also disappointed by the caged peacock.  Maybe it's normally free range and we just saw it at the wrong time, but if it has to spend any length of time in a cage that small, it's heartbreaking.

162971953.name: True Mexico, Clean Facilities
162971953.author: a TripAdvisor user
162971953.reviewBody: We visited as part of a packaged tour from Playa Maroma to Chichen-Itza. I was pleasantly surprised to find clean restrooms, a shower and changing area as well as a neat Mayan Indian performance in the Cenote itself. Unlike some other cenotes, this one is down actual stone stairs (instead of wooden) and can be slippery. Make sure to wear good walking shoes not flip-flops. The entrance fee is modest but be prepared to tip for the performance in the cenote. Some beautiful peacocks call this attraction home and if you have never heard them calling each other it is quite impressive. A small cafe and gift shop are also on site. I was pleased to find not only cold beer but also Diet Coke with Lime, Coke Zero and Sprite for very reasonable prices. My husband had two cold beers (XX Amber) and I had a Coke Zero and took along a Diet Coke with lime for under $10 US.\n\nThis was a couples visit for us but this attraction would be excellent for tweens or teens as well as all but the very old or very young. (due to slippery damp stone stairs)

159852210.name: Perfect solitary place
159852210.author: a TripAdvisor user
159852210.reviewBody: As expected we were the only visitors in this cenote. Good refreshing experience on the road from Coba to Valladolid (some 3 km before the Valladolid on your right side) for just 30 pesos per person. Facilities are prepared for lots of people and are ok (it seems they can offer much more attractions if arranged in advance, like horses, cooking, show, even accomodation). What we enjoyed at the end is the solitude of local environment. People were busy with their own routine works and not pushing us buy anything or asking questions. So we were like transparent observers of people, peacocks, dogs, chicken, horses, etc. Real Mexico!

156108785.name: Pleasantly surprising
156108785.author: a TripAdvisor user
156108785.reviewBody: We were on our way from Playa del Carmen to Merida and decided to make a "pit stop" at this cenote. We had no previous information of the place = to the best of our knowledge it is largely unknown, like most of the cenotes in the Yucatan peninsula. We have already seen several cenotes in the past and we knew more or less what to expect. The entrance fee was 25 pesos per person and judging by the fact that we paid the other day 50 pesos for another underground cenote with nothing much for facilities and appearance we almost decided to skip the effort of the visit to the cenote itself. We decided to give it a try and we discovered the nicest cenote we have seen to date. The other couple has seen many cenotes and they also are of the opinion that the Suytun is second only to the Chichen Itsa - but it must be mentioned that no one of us is a specialist in the field. There was practically nobody in the cenote - which was fine with us. The signage of the place is excellent and so are the toilets and shower facilities - clean, spacious, and well equipped with modern automatic soap and paper towel dispensers fit for top of the line tourist attractions and not for a God forsaken place which for us was in the middle of nowhere - kind of....\nThere is a second cenote nearer to the entrance - but it was under maintenance during our visit. The one year baby that was with us enjoyed the small farm chicken, geese, peacocks and horse they had on the facility and we enjoyed a rest in the two hamacs they hang in the trees nearby.

149754879.name: Lovely grotto
149754879.author: a TripAdvisor user
149754879.reviewBody: Very sweet spot. An underground large pond in a cave. But cannot judge for others. We were in our own group, entering pre-hours. For normal hours, I got the idea the place may be extremely crowded.

149225017.name: Nice place to stop and swim in the mystery
149225017.author: a TripAdvisor user
149225017.reviewBody: Fun place to stop between Tulum and Valladolid. The Ceynote was huge and we were the only visitors. A cool place to swim. The water was a bit murky but felt safe. Facilities were fine with a new changing room.

672581953.name: Really bad road and 4 times the price of every other cenote
672581953.author: a TripAdvisor user
672581953.reviewBody:
After diving in 4 cenote and having a swim in a few we went to visit Maya Cenote.  The travel is really bad and travel is slow due to pot holes and small villages.
When we arrived we discovered the price just to swim was $25.00 USD.
It may be a nice Cenote but we couldn’t justify paying $100 USD for the 4 of us.
Visit all the others they offer better value

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

670000265.name: Beautiful Nature Experience
670000265.author: a TripAdvisor user
670000265.reviewBody: Our guide, Julio Sirrra, provided an excellent account of the local flora & fauna as we drove to the cenote and to visit the archaeological site, Ek Balam. The drive was 2.5 hours one way. He demonstrated a wealth of information in a manner that was exciting and easy to understand.  As a guide who has appeared on National Geographic shows as well as Man vs Wild; his understanding of the jungle was an added bonus.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

669652883.name: Beautiful, huge cenote
669652883.author: a TripAdvisor user
669652883.reviewBody: I\'ve been to three cenotes and this one was, by far, my favorite. It\'s huge! There are a lot of activities inside (rapelling, ziplining, rubber rings, diving, walking on ropes or swimming). Loved it!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

665130570.name: you NEED to see this
665130570.author: a TripAdvisor user
665130570.reviewBody: you need to see this, pretty cool, you can rappel down the cenote (a must if you can)  you cannot bring cameras in the cenote BUT you can bring a GoPro (note to self; bring a gopro)

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

662965380.name: Rappelling into the cenote was amazing
662965380.author: a TripAdvisor user
662965380.reviewBody: Booked through AllTourNative tours in combination with a stop at Ek Balam. The lengthy bus ride was worth the drive. My 6 and 10 year old boys loved this stop. All four of us rappelled down into the cenote (I was nervous about the 6 year old but the staff took great care to help him). The zip lines and diving platform were highlight for the boys - though the larger zip line I would not allow my smaller boy to use - though I am very comfortable with my children\'s swimming abilities. They hated to leave for the second part of our tour and would have stayed all day. Joseline, our tour guide, was most amazing in creating an experience we could enjoy together.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

661755191.name: Best part of our trip!
661755191.author: a TripAdvisor user
661755191.reviewBody: Our guides were Joseline and Malu - we had a small group which was great! Originally, we planned to do our own trip to the ruins and a cenote but so happy we chose this route. Everything ran smoothly, the cenote was SO FUN and we were back at our hotel by 6!\n\nRecommend it to all!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

658323213.name: Cenote Mya /Ek Balam Tour
658323213.author: a TripAdvisor user
658323213.reviewBody:
Visited this site on a day tour with All TourNative tours.  Debby our guide was great.  She was good at explaining the Mayan welcoming and explaining how the tour would work.  My wife and I both chose to rappel into the Cenote.  Neat experience - it had been years since I had rappelled!  No experience necessary!  
Lunch was good and the food was tasty!

Carried on to tour Ek Balam - It was quiet there and we were able to explore the site and I climbed to the top.  Interesting to think of what it would have been like in it's day!!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

650929529.name: So fun!
650929529.author: a TripAdvisor user
650929529.reviewBody: Beautiful grounds, amazing cenote, delicious lunch. (You have to try the chocolate chicken!) Rappeled down into the cenote with my husband, brother and father in law, while mother in law chose to take the stairs. So beautiful and enchanting. The boys loved ziplining and jumping from the platforms, while I floated, and then watched from the platforms with my mother in law. Definitely worth the money\u2014but be prepared for a long and VERY bumpy ride (from Playa Del Carmen, at least.) Bring a book or something to do!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

649717415.name: Best Cenote Experience
649717415.author: a TripAdvisor user
649717415.reviewBody: This place is fantastic; a wonderful experience repelling into a fishbowl and swimming in the crisp waters of this underground wonder. The zip lines and the diving boards add to the great fun you will have at this natural wonder

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

649182576.name: You do not need to be super fit
649182576.author: a TripAdvisor user
649182576.reviewBody: The brochure we saw made me nervous. There were pictures of zip lines and rappelling into the cenote and a huge wooden staircase. There was no mention at all of the gently sloping tunnel - a gently graded ramp - that everyone uses to get from the water level back to the surface. This was a fairly recent construction and the reps selling the trip at our hotel had no knowledge of it. The guides also failed to tell me about it. So I did not get changed for a swim! I could easily have participated more in the "adventure" - rappelling, ziplining and the rest not being compulsory! It is a magnificent cave - one of the largest in the region - and you can walk in and out of it easily.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

647182528.name: WOW! SO NICE. GREAT STAFF
647182528.author: a TripAdvisor user
647182528.reviewBody: very friendly and knowledgable staff. From  Rappelling lines into the Cenote, to the zip lines in the Cenote. This park is an Archeological wonder.  jump in the crystal clear water and have a great afternoon. There is also a small tunnel to exit from.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

640407795.name: Cool experience
640407795.author: a TripAdvisor user
640407795.reviewBody: the experience was great I enjoyed the cenote however be advised that you can\u2019t bring your phone inside unless it is a GoPro camera so be advised that you will be paying $16 a photo or $50 for a dvd and $60 for a usb. Don\u2019t buy any drinks they are free at the end . :)

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

634914431.name: Unforgettable experience
634914431.author: a TripAdvisor user
634914431.reviewBody:
Great place to visit on way back from Chichen Itza or in its own right. We booked the trip as part of a tour. After being greeted and taking part in a simple Mayan ceremony made our way to change into our swimwear to enter the cenote. Limited changing space but lots of large lockers to put your belongings in. Towels are provided so you don't need to bring your own as we did.
 Incredible cenote, some of our party rappelled into the water or you can walk down the wooden stairs. Shafts of sunlight light the water in places but quite dark as most of the cenote is vaulted. 
The zip-wire is good fun but quite a drop from it into the water. Inflatable rings for you to sit in and enjoy the surroundings, even if the water is quite cold. Beautiful exit through a lit tunnel back out into the tropical forest.
Buffet lunch was fairly basic and beer/ branded soft drinks at extra cost. Well worth a visit!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

630252018.name: Cenote Maya Park Experience
630252018.author: a TripAdvisor user
630252018.reviewBody: I was recently in Cancun for a work sponsored event. We had a couple days to go to the beach and do an excursion, I am so glad that we decided to do a tour of Chichen Itza followed by the Cenote Maya Park.  Our guide Sara was wonderful, she made us feel welcome and her English was perfect.  The Cenote Maya park was beautiful, clean, peaceful and well staffed.  Our decent into the cave was very thrilling ( my wife and I never do anything like this) and we did it with ease. The Cenote was absolutely beautiful and once you got to the bottom we were surprised at the other adventures you could get into.  The beathrooms, showers, changing room and lockers were extremely clean and well staffed.  Lunch was provided ( quite delicious) and plenty of food options.  The gift shop was large and at the far end was a bar with complimentary  tequila shots/ margaritas ( what more can you ask for).  The bus ride back to the resort was long but the driver was great, the AC was on and the seat was comfortable.  Wonderful experience and I would recommend it to family, friends or anyone going to the Yucatan.  Oh one last thing to note was that the staff is all local and project illumination sponsored by Nikon employs local members of the community as well.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

621754570.name: Highlight of our trip
621754570.author: a TripAdvisor user
621754570.reviewBody:
This place is really great, this was our highlight of Mexico! And we only attended because it was part of our tour.

They provide towels, lockers, showers, and we had lunch. The lunch was amazing, this was the only place throughout our time in Mexico that catered to us as vegetarians - thank you to the owners for that, it was a welcome relief to have something proper to eat during our week!

Be sure to do the abseiling, its quite safe although I was surprised they didnt use a Grigri.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

620388820.name: Well Worth a Visit
620388820.author: a TripAdvisor user
620388820.reviewBody:
We hired a car from our hotel and visited this place on the way back from our trip to Chichen Itza. 

They provide the towels so no need to worry about bringing some from your hotel. Do bring a change of bathing suit/shorts tho! 

You have 2 options to enter, walk down the steps or absail. We went to absail, totally worth it, if you can relax and enjoy the view on your way down its amazing. We never done it before so we were pumped when we hit the water.

Be ready for the shock of the cold water, it is 20m under ground, limited light, that water was refreshing! 

Loved this place,  can't recommend highly enough.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

620300618.name: Great Activity for All
620300618.author: a TripAdvisor user
620300618.reviewBody: Just finished my experience at Cenote Maya Native Park and had a wonderful experience! All activites inside the park were amazing. From repelling into a cave, zip lines through the jungle into a cave and then snorkeling in these underwater caves were a fantastic experience. The lunch was great as well. Our tour guide Cesar was excellent and very knowledgeable and helpful. He then took us to Tulum and was very insightful about the history of the Mayan culture and civilization. Would definitely recommend this to anyone, and if you can get Cesar, it is an added bonus! All other guides I met were great as well!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

612107506.name: Awesome....would love to go again and again!
612107506.author: a TripAdvisor user
612107506.reviewBody: Rappelling down, refreshing feel of the water are all 10+. Kids wanted to stay there for the entire day!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

605149217.name: Great Time for All!
605149217.author: a TripAdvisor user
605149217.reviewBody:
We visited Cenote Maya with the AllTourNative group.  Our day was spent at Chichen Itza and afterwards, the beautiful Cenote.  Our guide German was amazing. A wealth of knowledge and charm! 

I was definitely a bit timid going down the repel.   For me the key was simply not to look down the 72 ft drop.  But once down, it was an amazing work of nature.   

The Cenote wasn’t crowded at all.  I don’t know if that was luck or by design.  So you have ample time to swim with your family.  My kids particularly loved the high zip-line platform and opted using it as a high-dive.  

The local community served a delicious luncheon buffet after our swim which turned out to be a surprising treat, since we didn’t know what to expect.   Fresh tortillas, honey potatoes,  rice and black beans, eggs and onions, and chicken. Everything was flavorful and the staff were kind and gracious. 

To close out the day, they offer margaritas (with and without tequila) so the entire family can partake.  

A day well spent and a must do for anyone (single, families, young or young at heart) in the area!!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

598316551.name: Fun for all who swim
598316551.author: a TripAdvisor user
598316551.reviewBody: This was part of our chichen itza tour. My teenage son and I had so much fun. It began with repelling into the cenote and 2 zipline heights. A couple of platforms to jump of of and plenty of refreshing swimming. They have inner tubes to just float on and stairs if you don\u2019t want to brave repelling into the cenote. Our tour was with alltournative and Tamara was our very excellent guide. We had a blast. They don\u2019t allow photography, but it\u2019s 50usd for a disk and totally worth it as they take many pictures and it\u2019s a once in a lifetime experience.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

592730111.name: Great fun for everyone, but the teenage boys loved it the most.
592730111.author: a TripAdvisor user
592730111.reviewBody:
We spent most of the day here. We repelled down into the cave which was pretty fun. It wasn't long before we were doing the zip lines, which were pretty fun. Even my mom did both of them. I did the higher one at least a dozen times.

There are two platforms to jump into the water. The high one is really high, so my wife and mom chickened out, but the boys and I did them. Make sure and point your toes!

Anyway, my mom and one of the boys did get a bit cold at times, but the rest of us thought the cool water was wonderful after the Mexican heat.

All in all, we were there for about 4 or 4 1/2 hours. The boys said it was the most fun they had in Mexico.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

591905550.name: Must see
591905550.author: a TripAdvisor user
591905550.reviewBody: My 19 year suggested this and what a great afternoon. I should say we went here after Chichen Itza on a package trip not cheap but would do it again.  On our trip we abseiled down into the cenote bit daunting as we and my wife are 50 but loved it.  Inside its swimming zip wires diving platforms and lots of photos. Nature side it\'s small Catfish bats and birds possibly Cave swallows but haven\'t quite decided yet. On our trip we got surprising good meal on the Maya village site plus quick tour which again was interesting. Be warned your photos $80 US which of course I bought!\n

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

590206792.name: Fun
590206792.author: a TripAdvisor user
590206792.reviewBody: A great place for kids to have fun and parents too. If driving on your own be prefer for a bumpy ride but worth the experience too. Rappelling was fun , 2 drifferent hights for the zip lines food was good too.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

575459437.name: EXCELLENT PARK
575459437.author: a TripAdvisor user
575459437.reviewBody:
we left chichen itza when it got too crowded (which was pretty early) and headed to cenote maya park. we were able to walk right up and purchase tickets to enter (no tour necessary if you have your own car/way to get there) it was a bit pricey compared to other cenotes, BUT WORTH IT!!
we got a traditional blessing ceremony, delicious buffet lunch, a rappel into the cenote, use of 2 different levels of zipline, a jumping platform, a small rope course, and swimming. the cenote is gorgeous!! 
***and we finished it all off with a spicy margarita (included) in a cayenne-rimmed glass!
my family enjoyed this activity WAY MORE than visiting Chichen Itza!!
(teens ages 20, 18, and 16)
***my only negative would be no cameras allowed (but i guess i understand why)

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

572047325.name: Wonderful Experience!
572047325.author: a TripAdvisor user
572047325.reviewBody: We visited Cenote Maya while on an excursion with allTOURnative experiences.  Our guide was great and we learned a lot about the Mayan culture while visiting.  My husband was able to do the repelling and zip lines in the cenote, that is the largest one we have visited.  It was absolutely stunning.  Lunch was simple, but very good.  We participated in a traditional Mayan ritual, as well. Two thumbs up!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

567089125.name: Don\u2019t chicken out\u2026it is only 22 meters down!
567089125.author: a TripAdvisor user
567089125.reviewBody:
As part of our trip to Ek Balam we visited the Mayan Cenote Park and it was awesome. I have swam in a cenote before and the cool water is refreshing on a hot day but they have all had stairs down. This site you have three options: 

1-Repell down 22 meters from the top – Recommended as you get to appreciate the whole cenote.

2-Walk down stairs. Makes sense if repelling is not possible.

3-A cave that has been widened. Last resort….and is the exit.

We repelled and my two girls (11 and 15) went first to maximize their time on the two zip lines and dive points. You will see small cat fish and bird flying around but all in all it is very refreshing. We purchased a photo package as they do have photographers in the cenote taking picks. You can bring your camera after for picks but the repel picture is priceless.

For us as group they made us a wonderful lunch as well. They had beans, rice, pasta chicken and salad as well as a couple other vegetable options. Beer and ice cream was not included but in my mind a must when you are on vacation.  

Would I return, yes it was very refreshing and fun.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

566842638.name: Great Experience
566842638.author: a TripAdvisor user
566842638.reviewBody: When you arrive, you take part in an authentic Mayan ceremony to get the blessing to enter the cenote.  To get into the cenote, you had to rappel about 50 feet into the water.  Of course the water is freezing cold, but you do get used to it.  It was very nice that we were not required to wear life jackets.  They said as long as you could swim you were good to go.  Which in seeing the options of things to do in the cenote, it made sense, as a life jacket doesn\'t work well when you are jumping off a 25 foot tall platform into the water.  There were two platforms, one at about 10 feet, the other at close to 25 feet.  There was also a zip line and a tarzan swing that both dropped you in the water at the end.  We had so much fun here, it was like being a kid again.  After the cenote fun, we got dried off, changed, and were treated to an authentic Mayan lunch.  The food was quite bland but good, I realize that they don\'t have much to work with.  All together with our trip to Ek Balam, this was the highlight of our trip.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

552571268.name: Beautiful and Authentic!
552571268.author: a TripAdvisor user
552571268.reviewBody: We loved loved loved this Park. If you\'re looking for an authentic experience that doesn\'t feel ruined by tourists visit. The blessing before entering the Cenote was particularly beautiful and it felt so right asking for permission before entering the Cenote.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

552287634.name: Tour of denote maya and EkBalam archeological site
552287634.author: a TripAdvisor user
552287634.reviewBody: Had a fantastic time with a very knowledgeable guid "Malu"..  a personable young lady.   The temple ruins of EkBalam were recently discovered and are in pristine condition. A breathtaking view awaits you.  As for the Cenote Maya...  wow it is truly amazing..you can rappel down to its pool... about 100 ft or climb down via stairway. Once there you can swim in the refreshing water.. zip line into it or jump right in.  It is enormous and awesome to just plain see it.  We took the tour via alternative.com well worth it.  A bit of a drive from hotel area but a must see.  A nice Mayan meal was also provided.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

551881555.name: Beautiful cenote
551881555.author: a TripAdvisor user
551881555.reviewBody: This is a beautiful cenote run by the local Mayan village. You get a special Mayan blessing to enter the cenote, can rapell down into the refreshing water, enjoy the 2 zip lines inside and more. The buffet lunch was great. A amazing experience.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

548926734.name: Amazing cenote with a bit of adventure
548926734.author: a TripAdvisor user
548926734.reviewBody: Perfect combination of visiting an amazing cenote (the cenote) with a bit of adventure: we did it with teenagers and they all enjoyed, going down with the rope and jumping in to the water from different platforms... It is also amazing simply swimming almost alone in the middle of it looking up to the top of the cave

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

547275650.name: #1 Highlight of my Trip!!
547275650.author: a TripAdvisor user
547275650.reviewBody:
I rappelled down the cenote and it was the best experience of my trip. I was scared like everyone else, but with the encouragement of the tour guide and my "yolo" attitude, I was able to do it and I had a blast! The cenote itself is very big. I went to another cenote in the Yucatan peninsula and it wasn't as nice so I am assuming this is one of the nicer ones. The water is so nice, cool and clean. The staff there are amazing - they really take care of you to make sure you have a life vest/floatation device if you can't swim and they come and check on you every now and then while you're in the water. 

The one downside is you can't bring cameras into the cenote because they want you to buy the photos that their professional photographers take of you. We ended up buying the photographs for $40USD, which is a lot, but it includes all 20ish photos they take of you rappelling plus some stock images, music and a video of the Mayan ceremony that we did on our tour. We were told that half of the proceeds go to the community so we felt good about purchasing the photos.

There's changerooms, lockers and towels there - all clean and tidy with great staff. There's also a coffee/drink shop where we had coffee and marguaritas after the swim.

I would absolutely recommend this site to other visitors. It seemed like it is barely visited as our tour group was the only one there so it's good if you want to avoid crowds.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

537296530.name: Absolutely FUN!
537296530.author: a TripAdvisor user
537296530.reviewBody: This place is awesome.  You can repel into the cenote.  You can also walk down however the repel is such a great experience.  I haven\'t ever repelled and I was so scared but I saw my 7 year old niece do it so I had to do it.  And it was so worth every moment.  The water below is cold and refreshing.\n

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

534151999.name: Don\u2019t bother
534151999.author: a TripAdvisor user
534151999.reviewBody: Massive rip off in the middle of nowhere. Very expensive compared to all the other cenotes - the basic entry per person was still over 700 pesos when the most we paid for a cenote up until then was 400 (and that included an amazing underground tour with a guide). Go spend your money elsewhere and get more for your money - grand cenote is lovely with turtles for around 150 pp, casa cenote is a mix of salt water and fresh for around 120 pp, sac actun is the underground one with beautiful stalactites, and dos ojos where we saw the most fish was only 100 pp.

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

509875028.name: Totally worth it! Ask for Anthony!
509875028.author: a TripAdvisor user
509875028.reviewBody: Totally worth it! Ask for Anthony, the best tour guide ever! He is very generous and you will learn a lot about Maya tribe. Welcoming and charming community! \nIn the morning, we did the ceremony to protect ourselves as Maya community tradition and them, we did a 25-meter-high abseiling and swimming in the Senote. AMAZING EXPERIENCE! We were scared but Anthony encouraged the whole group to surpass our fear and enjoy the view while abseiling! TOTALLY WORTH IT!!!!. There are zip lines down the Cenote and you can swim and relax. The buffet was delicious

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

509850277.name: Really amazing
509850277.author: a TripAdvisor user
509850277.reviewBody: This cenote is the most impressive one! Spit all the pictures u will be surprised! They have areas 11 meters deep! With trampoline! Infrastructure is good. Restaurant, showers, lockers, nice people. Price is not that cheap and this cenote is far away from Cancun, playa del Carmen and Tulum. U can combine Coba with this cenote, but if u are going better enjoy the day! Try to go through the speed roads, otherwise u be stuck at the small villages roads and will cost u a lot of time! But if u like patchwork, and fruits and bucolic small villages, u will enjoyed!

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

507242035.name: Great fun
507242035.author: a TripAdvisor user
507242035.reviewBody:
First experience of a Cenote 

This one is huge and filled with crystal clear water, cat fish and the odd bat

After a nice lunch and a blessing by a Mayan priest we rappeled into the Cenote 

Pretty cool - the kids loved it, as they did the zip lines and plunge jumps

 Great fun and culturally educational too

address.streetAddress: Road Chemaxenas de Uspibil - Chacmil, Km 3

500999730.name: Amazing Natural Wonder
500999730.author: a TripAdvisor user
500999730.reviewBody:
There are numerous cenotes in the region so it's very hard to choose between them all. I would absolutely love to come back and visit more. Each one is unique and has individual highlights. This one is very cave like; very little is exposed above ground. It is very dark but they do a good job of lighting it for full effect. It's also the largest in the region so it is a very special experience to repel down into it. You can either be hauled back up by them or you can climb a rope ladder back up yourself (with a safety harness of course). I don't recommend this option unless you are in excellent shape. I had a hard time getting to the top as the wooden pieces are very slippery from the water and it's very high up!
